Biography: Allan Kolski Horwitz was born in Vryburg, South Africa. He attended the University of Cape Town where he studied Philosophy and Literature. He is the author of four books of poetry: Call from the Free State, Saving Water, There are Two Birds at My Window and The Colours of Our Flag. He has also written and directed several plays, including The Pump Room, Comrade Babble, Boykie and Girlie, Jerico, Book Marks and Taking Everything into Account. He is a member of the Botsotso Jesters poetry performance group and of the Botsotso Publishing editorial board.
year_degree_institution: [" BA: University of Cape Town"]

Biography: Karen Press was born in 1956 in South Africa. She attended Red River College Polytechnic where she received a CAE in adult education. She also received a master's in creative writing degree from the University of British Columbia. She is the author of four books of poetry including: Spine, Exquisite Monsters, and Types of Canadian Women and of Women Who Are or Have Been Connected with Canada (volume 2). She has translated poetry from Afrikaans, primarily work by Antjie Krog, and she co-founded the publishing collective Buchu Books. She lives in Winnipeg, Canada.
year_degree_institution: [" CAE Adult Education: Red River College Polytechnic", " MFA, Creative Writing: University of British Columbia"]

Biography: Wilma Johanna Stockenström was born in 1933 in  Napier, South Africa. She studied at the University of Stellenbosch, obtaining a bachelor of arts degree in drama in 1952. She went on to work as a radio announcer in Cape Town. She also worked as a translator and actress. Her initial writing output was comprised of plays before she turned to poetry in the late 1960s, producing her first collection of poems, entitled Vir Die Bysiende Leser. She went on to become a highly regarded writer, publishing eleven well received collections and five novels. Several of her books have been adapted for stage or film.
year_degree_institution: ["1952 BA, Drama: University of Stellenbosch"]

Biography: Gert Vlok Nel was born in 1963 in South Africa. He studied English, Afrikaans, and History at the University of Stellenbosch. He is the author of Om Te Lewe is Onnatuurlik (Living is Unnatural), abook exploring his youth in Beaufort-Wes, a town in the South African countryside where mainly poor whites live. It won the Ingrid Jonker Prize. This collection was followed by a CD, Beaufort Wes Se Beautiful Woorde, an autobiographical sketch which contained poems, songs, and visual material that he performed across South Africa.
year_degree_institution: [" English, Afrikaans, and History: University of Stellenbosch"]

Biography: Ararat Iyob was born in 1953 in Eritrea. She was most well known for her political poetry. When she lived in Eriteria in the early years of her life, she was imprisoned for refusing to change a poem which was deemed disruptive by the Ethiopian government. After her release, she worked as an interpreter in a refugee camp in Sudan. She went on to write a book of poetry, Blankets of Sand, in which she describes the experiences of those who survived the struggle of war and exile. She also wrote poems in Tigrinya which blended sound, sense, and humor. She died in 2018.

Biography: Sandra A. Mushi was born 1984 in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. She is most well known for her collection of short stories and poems, Stains on My Khanga, published in 2014, which explores the lives of women, frequently dealing with oppressive situations and domestic violence. She grew up in the UK and was educated in Tanzania, Botswana, and South Africa. She studied Interior Design at Cape Peninsula University of Technology in Cape Town, and continued on to a career in interior design and architecture design. She is now a practicing interior designer and writer.
year_degree_institution: ["1999 Diploma, Interior Design: Cape Peninsula University of Technology"]

Biography: Musaemura Zimunya was born in 1949 in Mutare, Zimbabwe. He obtained a master's degree in literature at the University of Kent in England. He is the author of several poetry collections in English, including Selected Poems; Country Dawns and City Lights; Kingfisher, Jikinya, and Other Poems; and Thought Tracks. His Shona collections include Chakarira Chindunduma (Poems on the War). Zimunya is also the author of the short story collection Nightshift and the critical work Those Years of Drought and Hunger: The Birth of African Fiction in English in Zimbabwe. He taught at the University of Zimbabwe for several years, and he is currently the Director of Black Studies at Virginia Tech University.
year_degree_institution: ["1978 : University of Kent", "1979 MA, Literature: University of Kent"]

Biography: Hama Tuma was born in 1949 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. He studied Law in Addis Ababa University but was expelled for demonstrating against the regime of Emperor Haile Selassie in his final year of law school. Subsequently, he was also banned by three different Ethiopian governments for his commitment to human rights. He left Ethiopia and travelled extensively before settling in France. He is the author of several books of poetry, many of which have been translated into other languages such as English, Italian, French, and Hebrew.
year_degree_institution: [" Bachelor in Law: Addis Ababa University"]

Biography: Len Verwey was born in Mozambique in 1973. He is the author of two full-length collections of poetry, Loving the Dying and In a Language That You Know, and a poetry chapbook, Otherwise Everything Goes On, which was included in the box set Seven New Generation African Poets published by the African Poetry Book Fund. He is the recipient of a master's degree in comparative literature as well as a degree in commerce from UNISA and Stellenbosch, respectively. In addition to his poetic work, he has worked as an economist, researcher, and analyst in areas such as public finance, governance, and climate change.
year_degree_institution: ["2008 Master of Commerce: University of South Africa", "2001 MA, Comparative Literature: University of Stellenbosch"]

Biography: Niyi Osundare was born 1947 in Ikere, Nigeria. Poet, playwright and essayist, he has published many poetry collections including Moonsongs (1988) and Random Blues (2011). He went to the University of Ibadan, Nigeria for his undergraduate studies. He also received his masters from the University of Leeds in England, and in 1979, he received his PhD from York University. Osundare has received several awards including the Commonwealth Poetry Prize (1989 and 1994), the Tchicaya U Tam'si Award for African Poetry, and the Fonlon/Nichols Award for his contributions to African literature and advocacy of freedom of expression. In 2005, he was selected as a Fellow of the Nigeria Academy of Letters (NAL). A Professor of English at the University of New Orleans, he specializes in African Literature, Literature of the African Diaspora, and Literary Stylistic.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Ibadan", " : University of Leeds", " : York University"]

Biography: Fatima Naoot was born in Cairo in 1964. She is the author of five poetry collections, a book of criticism, and four translated anthologies. She attended Ein Al-Shams University for her undergraduate studies in architecture and worked in the field for ten years. She continued on to work full-time as a poet, writer, and translator. She has translated short stories by Virginia Woolf, a volume of American and English poetry, and a volume of short stories by John Ravenscroft. In 2016, she was sentenced to three years in prison for insulting Islam for comments she made online regarding the festival of Eid Al-Adha. She was later released.
year_degree_institution: ["1987 Architecture: Ain Shams University"]

Biography: Maria Eugenia Lima is an Angolan poet. Born in 1935, she studied in Angola and Portugal. She is the author of the Portuguese language books Entre a Pantera e o Esphelo, Binomio do Sangue, a book of poems, and A Cidade as Escuras, a play set in Angola in the late nineteenth century.
(CAP) Bio Sources (MLA): Chipasula, Frank and Chipasula, Stella. "Heinemann Book of African Women's Poetry." Oxford, Heinemann Educational Publishers, 1995.

Biography: Mamoudou Lamine Kane is a Mauritian poet and journalist. He is the author of three poetry collections, including A L'aune Des Espoirs and Les Musulmans d'Inal, which recalls the Mauritanian national independence day event in which twenty-eight men were hanged due to racial reasons. He writes for Mauritian daily newspapers and his own blog, www.mozaikrim.over-blog.com, and is also the director of the communication organization NEXUS PROD.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, Economic and Social Administration: University of Toulouse", " Master in Journalism: Professional Training Center for Journalism"]

Biography: Iman Mersal was born in 1966 in Egypt. She is the author of several books of poetry including, Mamarr Muètim Yasluh li Taèallum al-Raqs (A Dark Passageway is Suitable for Learning to Dance), which was selected as the best book of poetry in 1995 by polls conducted by a number of Egyptian magazines and newspapers. She attended Mansura University where she graduated with a Bacherlor degree. She also received a Master and Doctor of Philosophy degrees from the University of Cairo. She went on to become a professor at the University of Alberta.
year_degree_institution: [" BA: Al Mansoura University", " MA: Cairo University", " PhD: Cairo University"]

Biography: Abdelmadjid Kaouah was born in 1954 in Aïn-Taya, near Algiers. He holds a Master's in Modern Literature. During his studies he focused on Algerian poetry in French. He is the author of several French language books, including L'ombre du livre: poésie and Que pèse une vitre qu'on brise: Poèmes (Fragments). In 1995, he won the Sernet Prize at the Rodez International Poetry Days for La Maison Livide. The political upheaval in Algeria in the 1990s forced him into exile to the Toulouse region of France where he continues to work as a journalist.
year_degree_institution: [" Masters in Modern Literature: Unknown University"]

Biography: Wyk van Chris was born in 1957 in Soweto. He studied at Riverlea High School in Riverlea, Johannesburg. A critically acclaimed writer, he is the author of books such as Maria (1966), It is Time To Go Home (1979), Petroleum and the Orphaned Ostrich (1988), Oliver Tambo (1994), My Cousin Thabo (1995), April in the Cape of Storms (1996), The Year of the Tapeworm (1996), In Detention (2007), and others. He was awarded the Olive Schreiner Prize for his poetry collection titled "It Is Time to Go Home"(1979). He was also awarded prizes such as the Maskew Miller Longman Award and the Sanlam Literary Award. He died in Johannesburg on 3 October 2014.

Biography: Ogaga Ifowodo was born May 14, 1966 in Nigeria. He has written four books of poetry— Homeland and Other Poems, Madiba,The Oil Lamp, and A Good Mourning. He went to the University of Benin for his undergraduate degree in Law. He also received an MFA in Poetry and a PhD in English. He continued on to become a professor at Texas State University for several years. In 1997, he was arrested for criticizing the Sani Abacha regime and released in 1998. His poetry has won several awards, including The Association of Nigerian Authors (ANA) Poetry Prize; The ANA/ Cadbury Award; and The ANA/Gabriel Okpara Poetry Prize.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Benin", " : Cornell University\n", " : Cornell University\n"]

Biography: Mohamed Boudouik was born in 1953 in Jrada, Morocco. He is most well known for his collection The Delmon Wounds in which he drew heavily from his Arab heritage in ways similar to the early pioneers of Moroccan poetry, opting for modernism without compromising the millenary nature of the Arabic language. He studied Arabic Literature and English at Université Sidi Mohamed Ben Abdellah. He continued on to teach Arabic in a high school for several years and also worked as a columnist at the newspaper The Socialist Union. He lives in Fez, Morocco.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, Arabic Literature and English: Sidi Mohamed Ben Abdellah University"]

Biography: Blessing Musairi was born 1973 in Harare, Zimbabwe. She published her first poetry chapbook in 2015 with Akashic Books’ New Generation African Poets Box Set. The chapbook, titled Mitu’s Spice Tour, explores the emotional experiences and differing voices of a life lived in multiple places. Her poetry has been published in magazines, and anthologized. Musairi attended the University of Westminster for her Master's in Diplomatic Studies. She continues to work as a poet, screenwriter, and novelist, and is involved with the Crossing Borders Project, a partnership of the British Council, Lancaster University, and a range of partners in Africa.
year_degree_institution: ["1996 MA, Diplomatic Studies (with distinction): University of Westminster", "1997 Completed UK Bar Exams: Middle Temple Inns of Court"]

Biography: Arja Salafranca  was born in 1971 in Málaga, Spain to a Spanish father and South African mother. She is the author of three poetry collections: A Life Stripped of Illusions, The Fire in Which We Burn, and Beyond Touch. Her debut collection was awarded the Sanlam Prize and most recollection was co-winner of the South African Literary award. She attended the University of Witwatersrand where she obtained a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in creative writing. She has served as the lifestyle editor at The Sunday Independent. She lives in Johannesburg.
year_degree_institution: ["1993 African Literature and Psychology: University of the Witwatersrand", "2012 MA, Creative Writing: University of the Witwatersrand"]

Biography: Dieudonné Mukala Kadima Nzuji was born in The Democratic Republic of Congo in 1947. He graduated with a degree in literature from Lovanium University and went on to obtain a doctorate in letters and philosophy from the University of Liège. He has written several French language poetry collections and a novel, and he has contributed significantly to the landscape of Congolese literature with his work of literary criticism ‘Littérature Zaïroise de Langue Française.’ He currently lives in Brazzaville where he is a professor of African literature at Marien Ngouabi University.

Biography: Albert Nyathi was born in 1962 in Kafusi, Zimbabwe. He learned traditional praise poetry in school. He later began to write his own poems, inspired by the country’s freedom struggle. He attended the University of Zimbabwe where he graduated with an honors degree in English literature. He grew in popularity following his composition of the poem "Senzeni na?" written and performed in honor of the assassination of Chris Han, the South African politician. He is the author of one book of poetry, Echoes from the Kraal.
year_degree_institution: [" English Literature: University of Zimbabwe"]

Biography: Girgis Shoukry was born in Sohag, Egypt. He studied business but eventually started a career in art criticism. He worked as a drama critic for Radio and Television magazine in Cairo and a co-editor of the Aswaat Adabiyya (Literary Voices) series. In 1996, he published his first collection of poems, Fallen under my Soles. Subsequent collections included A Good Person in Conversation with Himself and The Importance of a Dog in a Play. His work explores the church, death, and the clash between childhood innocence and the adult world with its attendant rituals and biblical stories.

Biography: Dibussi Tande was born in 1968 in Buea, Cameroon. He is a political scientist, writer and poet who lives in Chicago. He obtained a “Licence” in Public law (1989) and a “Maitrise” in Political Science (1990) from the University of Yaounde. He also holds Master’s degrees in Political Science and Instructional Technology from Northeastern Illinois University and Northern Illinois University respectively. His poems have been published in several anthologies. His collections include No Turning Back: Poems of Freedom 1990-1993 (2007), Bearing Witness: Poems from a Land in Turmoil (2020) by Joyce Ashuntantang and Dibussi Tande, Their Champagne Party Will End! Poems in Honor of Bate Besong by Ashuntantang and Dibussi Tande (2008).
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Yaound\u00e9", " : University of Yaound\u00e9", " : Northeastern Illinois University", " : Northern Illinois University"]

Biography: Bewketu Seyoum was born in Mankusa, Ethiopia. He is the author of four volumes of poetry, two novels, two collections of short fiction, and several essays in Amharic. He attended Addis Ababa University where he studied psychology. He was honored as Ethiopian Best Novelist of the Year in 2008 and Best Young Author in 2009. He faced harassment because of his work at several now-banned news outlets. In 2012, he was attacked and severely beaten because of an essay he wrote about the Ethiopian saint Abune Takla Haymanot.  He went on to become a fellow at Brown University’s International Writers Project and an artist in residence at City Asylum of Pittsburg.

Biography: Nol Alembong is a scholar, poet, and prose writer from Cameroon. He is the author of three collections of poetry: Forest Echos (MiraClaire Publishing 2012), Passing Winds (2013, MiraClaire Publishing), and Green Call (2017, Notion Press). He also published the short story “Here, Where We Live” in Calalloo in 1980. He has taught as a Professor of African literature at the University of Yaounde I in Cameroon, and currently, serves as the Dean of the Faculty of Arts at the University of Buea, Cameroon.

Biography: Amina Said was born in Tunisia in 1953 to a Tunisian father and French mother. She studied English literature at the University of Paris, Sorbonne. She is the author of a dozen books of poetry and several Tunisian folk stories, short stories, and essays which draw from French, Arabic, and Mediterranean influences. She taught English for two years at a university in Tunisia and also translated several novels of the Filipino writer Francisco Sionil José.  Her work has been translated into several languages including Arabic, German, Turkish, English, and Italian.
year_degree_institution: [" English Literature: Sorbonne Universit\u00e9"]

Biography: Mohamed Sehaba was born in 1952 in Oran, Algeria. He is the author of several poetry collections in Algeria and in Paris, including Remparts, Chronique du Silence, and Les Chants de l’amant Oranais (Songs from the Oranais Lover) which explores the themes of abandonment and (dis)possession of nation and language, the power of names and naming, and the tensions inherent in the different possible paths forward for Algeria and its people. In addition to writing poetry, he worked as a cultural journalist for many years. He currently resides in Oran.

Biography: Obioma Paul Iwuanyanwu was born in 1962 in Umuahia, Nigeria. He is known mononymously as Obiwu. He went to Imo State University for his undergraduate degree in English and literature. He also received a master's and a doctor of philosophy degrees at the University of Jos and Syracuse University, respectively. He went on to become a professor in the humanities at Central State University in Ohio. He is the author of the poetry collections Rituals of the Sun and Tigress at Full Moon. He is also the author of several books of scholarly work such as he History of Nigerian Literature, 1772-2006.

Biography: Alda Neves da Graça do Espírito Santo was born in 1926 in São Tomé e Príncipe. In 1948, she began studying in Lisbon to become a primary school teacher. During her studies, she met students from other Portuguese colonies and joined a student association called the Casa dos Estudantes do Império. She went on to found ‘Centro de Estudos Africanos’ with other students interested in nationalism, many of whom would be prominent proponents of independence in their various countries. Upon her return to São Tomé e Príncipe, she worked as a teacher. In 1965, she was arrested and imprisoned for several months by the Portuguese authorities as a result of her identification with the African liberation movement. After independence, she held several high offices in the government, including as Minister of Education and Culture, Minister of Information and Culture, President of the National Assembly, and General Secretary of the National Union of Writers and Artists of São Tomé and Príncipe. She is the author of several books of Portuguese poetry. She died in Luanda, Angola in 2010.

Biography: Catherine Acholonu was born in 1951 in Orlu, Nigeria. Acholonu is the author of four poetry collections, including The Spring’s Last Drop (1985) and  Nigeria in the Year 1999 (1985) Acholonu, is also known for her scholarship, including the book Motherism: The Afrocentric Alternative to Feminism. Acholonu attended the University of Düsseldorf and was a professor at the Alvan Ikoku Federal College of Education in Owerri. She died in 2014.

Jamal Gabobe was born in Hargeisa, Somaliland. He earned his a Ph.D (Comparative Literature) from the University of Washington. He has published a book of poems ‘Love and Memory’ and an essay in the anthology ‘An Ear to the Ground: Presenting Writers from 2 Coasts.’ (2021). He was part of the Jackstraw Writers Program and has written on modern Egyptian literature and the Canadian tutor Magaret Laurence. He is currently an instructor/consultant at the University of Washington’s Center for Teaching and Learning.

Biography: Kavevangua Kahengua was born in Botswana and moved to Namibia in 1993. He is currently a special collections senior librarian at the University of Namibia. In addition to working as a librarian and a scholar, Kahengua is also the author of two collections of poetry, Dreams and Invoking Voices. He also serves as a volunteer African language expert in the Herero language for librarians cataloging materials in African languages.

Biography: Gagachua Clifton was born in 1987 in Nairobi. A poet and a novelist, he was awarded the inaugural Sillerman First Book Prize for African poets for his poetry collection titled Madman at Kilifi (2014). He attended Maseno University, where he studied Biotechnology. Gachagua’s work titled "The Cartographer of Water" was featured in a chapbook box set edited by Chris Abani and Kwame Dawes (Seven New Generation African Poets, Slapering Hol Press, USA). His novel, Zephyrion, was longlisted for Kwani? Manuscript Prize Project.

Biography: Yusuf Idris was born in Faqous, Egypt in 1951. He trained to be a doctor at the University of Cairo. After graduation, he worked at Kasr el Eini, the largest government hospital in Egypt. He supported Nasser’s rise to power but became disillusioned in 1954 at the time when his first collection of stories The Cheapest Nights was published. He also became a regular writer in the famous daily newspaper Al-Ahram. He is the author of several books and plays including Arkhas Layali (The Cheapest Nights), Al-Lahzat al-Harija (The Critical Moments), and Al-Farafir (The Farfoors).

Biography: Habib Tengour was born in 1947 in Mostaganem, Eastern Algeria. He studied sociology in France before returning to Algeria where he went on to teach at Constantine University. He is the author of several poetry collections, including: The Mother of the Pearle to the Soul, The Arc and Scar and Shales, and Gravity of the Angel. For his poetry, he was awarded the seminal prize Prix Européen de Poésie Dante. His poems have been translated into numerous languages such as English, German, Italian, and Arabic.

Biography: Mxolisi Nyezwa was born in 1967 in New Brighton, South Africa. He is the author of three books of poetry: Song Trials, New Country, and Malikhanye. His poetry is known for its amalgamation of the spiritual, political, and bleakness of the everyday. He won the Thomas Pringle National Award for Poetry, the most pretigious award given to a poet of South Africa. He is the editor of Kotaz, a multilingual South African literary journal based in the Eastern Cape. The journal works in language & writing projects in the rural and township communities in the Eastern Cape to help build a reading/writing culture.

Biography: Bongasu Tanla Kishani was born in 1944 in Kitiiwum, Cameroon. His first poetry collection, Konglanjo (Spears of Love without Ill-fortune) (1988), was the recipient of the 1990 Association of Nigerian Authors (ANA) award. In 2009, he published the volume of poems, A Basket of Kola nuts and Kpuà e Goè’ e Njeèm is his collection written in Laâm Nso’. His writings explore Cameroonian cultural values and identities. He also writes about colonialism, neo-colonialism and its influence on political structures and cultural dynamism. He holds a doctorate from the Sorbonne University, Paris, France (1988). Kishani is currently an Associate Professor of Philosophy at the University of Yawunde 1, Cameroon.

Biography: Dr Kristina Rungano Masuwa-Morgan was born in 1963 in Harare, Zimbabwe. She is most well known for her collection A Storm is Brewing, which explores war, womanhood, and the potential of love. She attended Catholic boarding schools near her hometown, and studied management and computer science in the United Kingdom. She holds a doctorate in business information technology systems, and has maintained a lifelong career in the computing industry in both Zimbabwe and the UK. She is currently the Director of Learning and Teaching for Engineering and Science at the University of Greenwich.

Biography: Abdel-ilah Salhi was born in 1968 in Beni Mellal, Morocco. He has a bachelor's degree in English and a master of arts degree in English literature. In France, where he moved in 1990, he explored the French literary scene and became acquainted with many Arab expatriate writers, including Iraqi poet Abdelkader Al Janabi. Through him, he frequented the Arab surrealist circle in Paris. This inspired him to began his own literary magazine Israf (Excess), which had a significant impact on the prose poem and surrealism in Morocco. He works as a journalist and radio correspondent in France.

Biography: Maina wa Kinyatti was born in 1944 in Kenya. He is most well known for his collections Thunder from the Mountains: Poems and Songs from the Mau Mau and A Season of Blood: Poems from Kenyan Prisons. He went to Farmington University for his undergrad. He also received a masters in History at the University of Michigan. In 1982, he was arrested during the Moi administration for possessing seditious literature and was imprisoned for six years. He subsequently fled to Tanzania before receiving asylum from the United States. He is the recipient of several awards, including PEN Freedom to Write Award.

Biography: Abdallah Zrika was born in 1953 in Casablanca, Morocco. He is the author of several books of poetry, including ‘Dance of the Head and the Horse,’ which was an immediate success with the younger Moroccan generation. In 1978, he was arrested and condemned to two years in jail for disturbing public order with his poetry and for supposed crimes against “the sacred values” of his country. Since his release in 1980 he has continued his career as a writer, becoming one of Morocco’s major voices. Several of his books have been translated into French. In addition to his literary interests, he holds a degree in sociology.

Biography: Édouard Maunick was born in 1931 in Flacq District, Mauritius. He is the author of several poetry collections including Les Oiseaux du Sang (1954), De Sable et de Cendre: Poèmes (1996) and Mascaret ou Le livre de la mer et de la mort, which was influenced by the Nigeria-Biafra war. Exile, captivity, history and identity are central themes in his work. After attending teacher's training college, he taught for nine years and worked as a librarian for the Municipality of Port Louis. At age twenty-nine, he moved from Port Louis to Europe in 1960 where he worked as writer and director for Coopération Radiophonique. Poet, critic and translator, he is the recipient of the 2003 Grand prix de la francophonie and the 1977 Apollinaire Prize for Poetry. He joined UNESCO in 1970 and served as the director of UNESCO collection of representative literary works and was a member of the Haut conseil de la Francophonie and a Chevalier des Arts et Lettres. Maunick was appointed as Mauritian ambassador to South Africa in 1994. He died in 2021 in Paris.

Biography: Sally Ann Murray was born 1961 in Durban, South Africa. She first gained recognition as a poet for her collection Shifting, which won the 1991 Sanlam Award for Literature and the 1989 Arthur Nortje/Vita Award for poetry. She attended the University of Natal, Durban (now University of KwaZulu-Natal) for her MA in South African Literature, and for her Doctor of Philosophy in Cultural and Literary Studies. She serves as Chair of the English Department at the University of Stellenbosch, where she publishes research in autobiography and autoethnography, writing and gender, and creative writing as academic research, among other areas.

Biography: Jeremy Cronin was born 1949 in Durban, South Africa and raised in a middle-class white family in Simonstown. He is the author of More than a Casual Contact (2006), Inside and Out (1999), and Even the Dead (1997). In July 1976, Cronin was incarcerated for his anti-apartheid activities against the state by working with banned liberation organizations. His work examines the freedom struggle, political and emotional landscape of the South African experience. He was released in May 1983. He became a Member of Parliament in 1999 and in 2012, he was appointed the Deputy Minister of Transport and Public Works. He holds a BA degree from the University of Cape Town and studied at the Sorbonne University in Paris, France between 1972 and 1974. He taught Philosophy at the University of Cape Town, where he coedited the volume, Ideologies of Politics.

Biography: Nontsizi Mgqwetho was born in South Africa. Virtually nothing is known about her, but she exploded onto the literary scene in the 1920s, contributing over 95 Xhosa language poems to the Johannesburg newspaper Umteteli wa Bantu. She was the first and only female poet to produce a substantial body of work in Xhosa. She withdrew from the poetry scene for two years and then reappeared between December 1928 and January 1929 with two final poems. She disappeared again and nothing has been heard from her subsequently. Her poems confronted male dominance, ineffective leadership, Black apathy, White malice and indifference, economic exploitation and the tragic history of nineteenth-century territorial and cultural dispossession. A collection of her poems, The Nation’s Bounty, was collected in the original Xhosa along with translations by Jeff Opland.

Biography: Nimrod Bena Djangrang was born in 1950 in Chad. He attended university in Abidjan in Côte d'Ivoire where he went on to teach in colleges and high schools. He also obtained his doctoral degree in 1996 and became the editor-in-chief of the journal Aleph for several years. He became a professor of philosophy at the University of Picardie Jules-Verne as well as the founder of the Francophile literary magazine Agotem, published by Obsidian. In 2008, he received the Édouard-Glissant prize, intended to honor a significant artistic work of our time which aligned with the poetic and political values of the philosopher and writer Édouard Glissant. He also received the prestigious Apollinaire Prize for his poetry collection Petit Éloge de la Lumière Nature.

Biography: Osama al-Danasuri was born in Disuq in the Nile Delta. He studied maritime sciences at the University of Ismailia in 1984. He went on to write several books of poetry including: Hareshefo al-gahme (Scales of the sullen) and Methlu dhe'ben a'ma (Like a Blind Wolf). He is considered one of the greatest Egyptian cultivators of the prose poem and one of the most important Arab poets. He passed away on January 4th, 2007 and was buried in his hometown. His only narrative book, Kalbeya al-harem, kalbeya al-habib, was published posthumously to great success.

Biography: Taban Lo Liyong was born in 1939 in Acholiland, South Sudan. A prolific and critically acclaimed writer, he attended the National Teachers College in Kampala. He earned his undergraduate degree at Knoxville College in Tennessee, and postgraduate degree at Howard University. He is the author of poetry collections such as Frantz Fanon's Uneven Ribs (1971), Another Nigger Dead (London, Heinemann, 1972), Ballads of Underdevelopment (Kampala, East African Literature, Bureau, 1976), The Cows of Shambat (Zimbabwe Publishing House, Harare, 1992), Words that Melt a Mountain (Nairobi, East African Educational Publishers, 1996), Carrying Knowledge Up a Palm Tree (1997), Corpse Lovers and Corpse Haters (2005), After Troy (2021), Meditations in Limbo (Nairobi, Equatorial, 1970), The Uniformed Man (Nairobi, East African Educational Publishers, 1971), The Meditations of Taban lo Liyong (1978), and others. He was the first African graduate from the University of Iowa Writer's Workshop.

Biography: Viola Aloo is a poet born and raised in Cameroon, who now lives in the United States. (need birth date) She is the author of the poetry collection Bird From Africa (2015, Akashic books). Aloo was shortlisted in 2013 and 2014 for the Brunel University African Poetry Prize. She received her bachelors in psychology from the University of California Davis and a Masters degree in Anthropology for the University of Michigan Ann Arbor. She studies creative writing at American River College (get years for degrees).

Biography: Ribka Sibhatu was born in 1962 in Asmara, Eritrea.  She is the author of the Tigrinya and Italian books of poetry, Aulò: Canto-Poesia Dall'Eritrea and Cittadino Che non Cè. L'immigrazione Nei Media Italiani. She was imprisoned in 1979 for refusing to marry an Ethiopian officer and released a year later. She fled the country, living in Ethiopia where she completed her secondary education and studied at the Istituto Tecnico Galileo Galilei. She moved to France afterwards, and then to Italy where she settled in Rome. Sibhatu received a doctor of philosophy degree in communication studies from La Sapienza. She worked for the city council in Rome from 2002 to 2005 as a consultant on inter-cultural politics. In 2006, she became a member of the scientific committee for inter-cultural affairs of the Italian Ministry of Education, Universities and Research. In 2012, she produced the documentary Aulò: Roma Postcoloniale.

Biography: Amin Khan was born in Algiers in 1956. His has written several books including Les Mains de Fatma, Archipel Cobalt, and Arabian Blues. He studied at the University of Algiers, the University of Oxford, and the Institut d’Études Politiques in Paris, and went on to become a diplomat and international civil servant at the United Nations (New York), The World Bank (Washington, D.C.) and UNESCO (Paris). He is the winner of the Prix de Poésie “François Coppée” de l’Académie Française in 2012 and Le Prix Méditerranée Nikos Gatsos in 2012 for Arabian Blues. He lives in Paris with his family.
year_degree_institution: [" Philosophy: University of Algiers", " Economics: Oxford University", " Political Science: Paris Institute of Political Studies"]

Biography: Joan Hambidge was born 1956 in Aliwal North, South Africa. Poet, reviewer and literary theorist, she is well known for her engagement with Afrikaans literary traditions. Her work covers a range of subjects including city life, love and family and ars poetica. Her book of poetry, Bitterlemoene (1986), was the recipient of the Eugène Marais Prize. She also received the ATKV Poetry Prize for her collection, Visums (2011). She earned a BA from Stellenbosch University and an MA from the University of Pretoria. She also holds two doctoral degrees, the first from Rhodes University and the second from the University of Cape Town. Hambidge is a professor at the School of Literature and Languages at the University of Cape Town.

Biography: Petra Müller was born 1935 in Botrivier, South Africa. She is most well known for her collection Die Aandag Van Jou Oë (The Attention of Your Eyes), published in 2002 and subtitled “Poems for Love.” The collection explores love and the loss of her husband. She attended Stellenbosch University for her Bachelor of Arts in English and Afrikaans-Dutch in 1955. She began her working life as a journalist, but was forced to retire from the National Press when she was married and had children, during which time she wrote both prose and poetry. After her children were grown, she continued on to a lifelong career as a journalist, editor, and finally, editorial board member at Table Mountain Publishers. In 2005 she won the Herzog Prize for Afrikaans Poetry.

Biography: Bahia Mahmud Awah was born in 1960 in the disputed Western Sahara region. He is the author of several books, including The Teacher Who Taught Me on a Wooden Slate, Refugee Verses, Little Reflections and Poems, and How My Grandfather Almost Starved to Death. Due to the start of the Western Saharan war, he left home for Cuba where he obtained his undergraduate degree at the University of Havana studying telecommunications. He also received a Master's in Public Anthropology from the Autonomous University of Madrid, where he later became a professor of Social Anthropology.

Biography: Kobena Eyi Acquah was born in 1952 in Winneba, Ghana. A lawyer and poet, Acquah is the author of the 1984 poetry collection The Man Who Died: Poems 1974 -1979, which won the 1985 British Airways Commonwealth Prize for Poetry. Other collections include: Music for a Dream Dance (1989), Rivers Must Flow and No Time For A Masterpiece (1995). Acquah attended the University of Ghana, Legon and Ghana Law School. He was a fellow of the International Writing program at the University of Iowa and the 1993 President of the Ghana Association of Writers.

Biography: Mutombo Nkulu-N’Sengha was born in the Democratic Republic of Congo. He is the author of Bela-Wenda, a book of poetry. He attended Major Seminar St. Paul where he obtained an undergraduate degree in Philosophy and Theology. He went on to receive two Master's degrees and a PhD. He currently teaches African religions, American religious diversity, and comparative religions at California State University. He also serves as the editor of the Congo Times. In addition to poetry, he has written extensively on Bumuntu philosophy.

Biography: Dannabang Kuwabong was born 1955 in Nanville, the Upper West Region of Ghana. He has written several books of poetry, including Visions of Venom, Echoes from Dusty Rivers, and Voices from Kibuli Country. He went to the University of Ghana for his undergrad in English. He also received a Magisteriate in Environmental Studies at York University in Canada, a masters degree in Modern Poetry from Stirling University in the UK, and a PhD in English from McMaster University in Canada. He went on to become a professor at Rivers State College of Education, University of Port-Harcourt, University of Ghana and McMaster University, Canada. He teaches Caribbean literature at the University of Puerto Rico, San Juan.

Biography: Thierry Sinda is a French poet of Congolose origin. He is the author of several French language books of poetry, including: “Anthologie des Poèmes d’Amour des Afriques et d’Ailleurs” (Anthology of love poems from Africa and elsewhere) and Chant du Black Paname. In addition to his literary pursuits, he is a film critic for Amina Magazine and a university professor. For the last decade, he has been building a movement of black writers called Néonégritude, a revival of the Négritude movement of the 1930s. He is also the leader of Le Printemps des Poètes d’Afrique et d’Ailleurs, a festival which brings together black poets to showcase African culture.

Biography: Fatima Mahmoud was born in Tripoli in the mid 20th century. She is most known for her poem "Here I Am Sleep" which appeared in Poems for the Millenium, volume IV. She worked as a journalist in Libya between 1976 and 1987. She then moved to Cyprus where she founded the notable magazine Modern Sheherzade. She later returned to Libya but was forced to seek asylum in Germany because of the hostility the regime exhibited toward her in response to her writing.

Biography: Buma Kor is a poet from Cameroon. He is most well known for his book of poetry Searchlight Poems. He has a masters in business administration and publishing from Oxford Brookes University. He organized several writing and artist workshops and provided a platform for writers on a radio program entitled the Young Writers Forum. As a result of these, he compiled the first Anglophone Cameroon Writers anthology which was exhibited at the first Agro-pastoral show in 1973. With very few foreign publishers of Anglophone Cameroonian writing, Kor started his own publishing company in 1974. He went on to work as Publishing Co-ordinator at the UNESCO Centre for Book Promotion in Africa.
year_degree_institution: ["1988 MA, Business Administration and Publishing: Oxford Brookes University"]

Biography: Phaswane Mpe was born in 1970 in Polokwane, South Africa. He is the author of the acclaimed novel Welcome to Our Hillbrow and a collection of poems and short stories, Brooding Clouds. He attended the University of Witwatersrand as an  undergraduate student in African Literature. He also received a diploma in publishing from Oxford Brookes University and a Master's in African literature from University of Witwatersrand. He continued on to become a professor in African literature. He died in 2004 from unknown causes.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, African Literature: University of the Witwatersrand", " Diploma, Publishing: Oxford University", " MA, African Literature: University of the Witwatersrand"]

Biography: Werewere Liking was born 1950 in Cameroon. She is most well known for her experimental and avant-garde style of writing. Considered one of the leading figures of women writers in Francophone Africa, she founded Ki-Yi Mbocke Village (meaning "ultimate universal knowledge" in Bassa), a training center and community of artists including writers, painters, sculptors and more. In 2002, she was the recipient of the Prince Claus Award for her contributions to cultural and societal development. Writer, performer, and playwright, Liking has championed Panafricanism over the years, and she employs diverse artistic expressions to transcend cultural differences and celebrate African authenticity.

Biography: Megan Hall was born in 1972 in Cape Town. She is best known for her collection of poems Fourth Child, which won the Ingrid Jonker Prize for 2008. She went to university of Cape Town for her undergraduate degree in English and Latin. She was the publishing manager for dictionaries and school literature in English at Oxford University Press, South Africa. She edited poetry and fiction for New Contrast and took part in Young Voices, the 2004 South African Online Writers’ Conference and was selected for the 2005 Crossing Borders programme, the British Council-sponsored writer’s mentorship.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Cape Town"]

Biography: Hassaan Youssri was born in Cairo in 1964. He attended Ain Shams University where he studied history. He went on to become the editor of multiple papers such as Horiyaty (My Freedom) and Al-Masaa. He is a member of the Supreme Cultural Council Selection Committee for the Al-Kitab Al-Awal (First book) Series. He is the author of two poetry collections, including Qabal Nihayat al-Mashhad (Before the Scene is Over). He is also the author of several scholarly papers on colloquial poetry and the relationship between poetry and mass media.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, History: Ain Shams University"]
(CAP) Bio Sources (MLA): Metwalli, Mohamed. "Angry Voices: An Anthology of the Off-beat New Egyptian Poets." Indiana, University of Arkansas Press, 2003.

Biography: Barbara Fairhead was born in the UK in 1939, and has lived in South Africa since 1948. She is an award-winning artist, sculptor, fiction writer, and the lyricist for the band Red Earth & Rust. She has published two books of poetry which include "And Now You Have Leapt Up To Swallow the Sun" (1997) and "Word and Bead: The Presentation of a Journey" (2001). Her first novel, "Of Death and Beauty" was published in 2013 by Sunstone Press, Santa Fe, New Mexico. Its sequel, "Whereof One Cannot Speak" was published in 2017.

Biography: Patrice Nganang was born in 1970 in Yaoundé, Cameroon. Poet, novelist, and essayist, he is the author of poetry collections elobi (1995) and Apologie du Vandale (2006). As a literary scholar, his work investigates subjects related to violence, postcolonial African literature and cultures. In 1992, he received his MA from the University of Yaoundé. He also earned his Ph.D. in comparative literature at the Johann Wolfgang Goethe University. In 2003, he was Shortlisted for the Fonlon-Nichols Award for Extraordinary Achivement in Scholarship and literature of the African Literature Association (ALA). Nganang is a Full Professor of Literary and Cultural Theory at State University of New York, Stony Brook.
year_degree_institution: [" : Johann Wolfgang Goethe University", " : University of Frankfurt", " : University of Yaound\u00e9", " : University of Yaound\u00e9"]

Biography: Monique Kwachou is a Cameroonian author and scholar. Her short stories have been published in several anthologies, and her poetry collection, Writing Therapy, was published in Cameroon by Langaa RPCIG in 2010. Kwachou is the founder and executive director of Better Breed Cameroon, a nonprofit devoted to youth development. She has also worked as a Gender Studies Instructor at University of Buea, and as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow for the Higher Education and Human Development Research Group, UFS-South Africa.

Biography: Ali Moussa Iye was born in Djibouti. He holds a doctor of philosophy degree in the political sciences from the Institute of Political Sciences in Grenoble, France.  He has worked as a journalist, editor, and press and audiovisual director in Djibouti. He joined the UNESCO in 1997 as Coordinator of the Programme of Culture of Peace in the Horn of Africa and then of the Programme on the Fight against Racism and Discrimination. Before leaving the UNESCO in 2019, he directed two important programmes: The Routes of Dialogue (Slave Route Project, Silk Roads Project) and the General and Regional Histories Project. He is the coordinator of the general history of Africa project. Dr. Moussa Iye is involved in research in political anthropology and has published several books on endogenous democratic institutions and practices in the Horn of Africa. He is the founder of a new think tank called “AFROPROSPECTIVE: A Global Africa Initiative.”
year_degree_institution: [" PhD, Political Sciences: Institute of Political Sciences"]

Biography: H.J. Pieterse was born in 1960 in Wageningen, Netherlands while his father was undertaking a doctoral degree. His family returned to South Africa in 1962 where he went on to study at the University of Pretoria and the University of South Africa, eventually obtaining a doctorate degree. He is the author of two books of poems: Alruin (‘Mandrake’) and Duke Bluebeard’s Castle. He is a professor of creative writing at the University of Pretoria. He is the co-founder of "Die Bekbrekers" which organizes poetry slams and monthly poetry readings.
year_degree_institution: ["1995 PhD, Literature: University of South Africa"]

Biography: Menzi Thango was born in South Africa. He is an academic, poet, essayist, and editor. He is the author of eight books; Unqambothi Lobunkondlo and Impophoma, collections of isiZulu poems, were published by Pelmo Books while Imvelaphi Yobuntu and Igula Lolwazi, IsiZulu essays, and Imivimbo, an IsiZulu novella, were published by Bhiyoza Publishers. He has a Master’s degree in African Languages, majoring in isiZulu sociolinguistics.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of the Witwatersrand", " : University of South Africa", " : University of South Africa"]

Biography: Robert Berold was born in 1984 in Johannesburg, South Africa. He is the author of four books of poetry including The Door to the River (1984), The Fires of the Dead (1989), Rain Across a Paper Field (1999) and All the Days (2008). He explores shame, beauty (nature in Eastern Cape) and the complex layers of contemporary South African living. From 1989 to 1999, Berold served as the editor for the poetry journal New Coin. He received his BSc in Chemical Engineering from the University of Witwatersrand in 1969, and an MA in Economics and English Literature from Cambridge University in 1972. Founder of Deep South Publishing, he focuses on raising funds to encourage writers and publish poetry by South Africans.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of the Witwatersrand", " : University of Cambridge"]

Biography: Brian Ernest Walter was born in Port Elizabeth in 1956. He has taught at Chapman Senior Secondary School in Gelvandale, PE, and at the University of Fort Hare, Alice for nineteen years. He obtained a doctorate from Rhodes University, studying Sol Plaatje’s use of the romance mode to project a vision that could avert potential tragedy and using cross-cultural knowledge and sympathy to transform and translate tragic unkindness into a more human, moral understanding. He is the author of several literary and critical works, including: Tracks and Baakens, Mousebirds, and Groundwork: An Introduction to Reading and Writing about Poetry. He won the 1999 Thomas Pringle Award for poetry published in journals and the 2000 Ingrid Jonker Prize for his collection Tracks.
year_degree_institution: [" PhD, English Literature: Rhodes University"]

Biography: Kolanyane-Kesupile was born in January 1988 in Francistown. She is one of the first transgender people to come out openly in Botswana. She received a bachelor's degree in drama and dramatics from the University of the Witwatersrand and earned a master's degree in human rights, culture and social justice from Goldsmiths, University of London where she was Chevening Scholar in 2016. She is the founder of the Queer Shorts Showcase Festival, which is the first and only LGBT themed theater festival in Botswana. She has also written for Peolwane Magazine, The Kalahari Review, The Washington Blade, and AfroPUNK.com.
year_degree_institution: ["2010 BA, Drama and Dramatics: University of the Witwatersrand", "2017 MA, Human Rights, Culture, and Social Justice: Goldsmith College"]

Biography: Charl-Pierre Naudé was born in 1958 in kwaZulu Natal, South Africa.  He went to the University of Stellenbosch where he studied literature and philosophy. He went on to work as a journalist. He is the author of three books of poetry, Die Nomadiese Oomblik (The Nomadic Moment), In Die Geheim van Die Dag (Against the Light) and Al Die Lieflike Dade (All Those Lovely Acts). Poetry International in Rotterdam devoted a translation project to his work, and several translations of his poems have appeared in both Dutch and Flemish magazines. He currently lives in Johannesburg.

Biography: Ahmad Yamani was born in 1970 in Cairo, Egypt. He graduated from Cairo University in 1992, receiving a bachelor of arts degree in Arabic literature. He also received a doctorate in Arabic philology from Complutense University in Madrid. He went on to work at the broadcaster RTVE. He has published several books of poetry in Arabic, and one in his adopted language Spanish. Yamani has translated numerous Spanish-language writers into Arabic, among them José Ángel Valente, Rubén Darío, César Vallejo, Adolfo Bioy Casares, Miguel Casado, Rosendo Tello, Ángel Guinda, Agustín Porras, and Roberto Bolaño. His collections of poems include: Mid Rooms, Wrong Places, and Flowers in the Head.
year_degree_institution: ["1992 BA, Arabic Literature: Cairo University", " PhD, Arabic Literature: Universidad Complutense de Madrid"]

Biography: Rustum Kozain was born 1966 in Paarl, South Africa. He is most well known for his collections of poetry This Carting Life and Groundwork. He went to the University of Cape Town for his masters in English and Literature/ Letters. He also received his masters at Bowling Green University. He continued on to become a Professor at the University of Cape Town in South Africa. He has received numerous awards for his poetry, including the Nelson Mandela Poetry Prize, The Thomas Pringle Award and Ingrid Jonker Prize.

Biography: Mbongeni Khumalo was born in 1976 in South Africa. He is the author of two poetry collections, Apocrypha and Throbbing Ink. He is also the recipient of a merit award from the English Academy of South Africa. In addition to his books of poetry, his poems have been published in New Coin, Global Fire, Tribute, Timbila and Botsotso. A performance artist, he regularly performs his poetry in his native South Africa.

Biography: Kelwyn Sole was born in Johannesburg in 1951. He studied English at the University of Witwatersrand and received a master's degree from the University of London’s School of Oriental and African Studies, and a doctor of philosophy degree from Witwatersrand on the subject of the South African Black Consciousness Movement of the 1970s. He worked for some time in Namibia, but was expelled from the country in 1980 under the Undesirable Aliens Act. On returning to South Africa, he was first appointed by the South African Committee for Higher Education. Later, he was appointed at the University of the Witwatersrand, Khanya College, and in 1987, at the University of Cape Town, where he is now Professor of English. He is the author of six collections of poetry, including The Blood of Our Silence and Absent Tongues for which he has received several awards, including the Olive Schreiner Prize and the Thomas Pringle Award for Poetry.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, English: University of the Witwatersrand", " MA, 1975: SOAS at University of London", " PhD: University of the Witwatersrand"]

Biography: Michael Weeder was born in Capetown, South Africa. He earned his BA (Hons) and an MA in History from the University of the Western Cape (UWC). He is the author of Lockdown, Love and Lament (2020, African Lives) and The Promise of Memory (2021, African Perspectives Publishing). He is also the Dean of St George’s Cathedral in Cape Town.

Biography: Boujema El Aoufi was born in 1961 in Taza, Morocco. He began writing in 1986 and went on publish two collections of poetry Bayadat Shayiqa and Asdiqa’ Yughadiruna Hunjurati, characterized by their ordinary language and concern for everyday life. He is a member of both the Union of Moroccan Writers and the House of Poetry in Morocco. He is also the recipient of the 2001 Shariqa Award for Arab Creative Writing offered by the Ministry of Culture and Communication in the United Arab Emirates. He organizes poetic events in Morocco designed to promote the country’s poetry.

Biography: Corsino António Fortes was born 1933 in Mindelo, Cape Verde. Poet and diplomat, he is known to explore his country’s independence and path to liberation in his writings, as well as themes of exile, oppression and identity. His first book, Pão & Fonema (1974), addressed the conditions of island populations under Portuguese rule where Cape Verdeans suffered from hunger. The poet engages the political and cultural aspects of the Cape Verdean life and captures the islands' distinctive African nature. Fortes served as the first Ambassador of Cape Verde to Portugal from 1975 until 1981. He was the president of the Association of Cape Verde Writers (2003-2006) and the founder of Cape Verdean Academy of Letters. He studied Law at the University of Lisbon in 1966 and worked as a professor and judge of the Labour Court.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Lisbon"]

Biography: Abdelkarim Tabbal was born 1931 in Chefchaouen, Morocco. He is the author of several Arabic language poetry collections, including: The Way to Man, Broken Things, and The Passenger. He attended Karaouine University where he studied Islamic Studies. In 1954, he began publishing poetry. He founded Al-Shira’a magazine and was one of the founding members of the Shefshaoun Festival of Poetry. His work has been translated into several languages.

Biography: Abu Bakr Solomons worked as a teacher and principal for more than forty years in high schools and primary schools on the Cape Flats and continues to serve the educational community at various institutions on a part-time basis. He studied English language and literature at three different South African universities and abroad. His poems have been published in Tribute, Akal (the journal of the Congress of South African Writers), Poetry Institute of Africa, Botsotso poetry journals, Sol Plaatje European Union anthologies, Sections of Six (Botsotso), New Coin (poetry journal of Rhodes University, Grahamstown) and New Contrast. His debut collection of poetry A Season of Tenderness and Dread was published by Botsotso in 2018 and received a commendation from the judges of the Ingrid Jonker Poetry Prize in that year.

Biography: Magdy El-Gabry was born in 1961 in Egypt. He studied at a traditional Islamic school, learning the Quran before attending the Institute for Agricultural Studies and graduating in 1983. He also received a master's degree from the Higher Institute of Folkloric Art. He served as the editor of the General Egyptian Book Organization’s Young Library Series and of Theatre Magazine. He is the author of several collections including, Aghostos, (August), Bizabt wa Ka'innu Hasal (Just as if It Happened) and Ayyel bi-Yestaad el-Hawadeet (A Kid Chasing Stories). He died in 1999 of cancer.
year_degree_institution: [" : Institute of Agricultural StudiesHigher Institute of Folkloric Art"]

Biography: Donald Parenzee was born in 1948 in South Africa. He attended the University of Cape Town where he obtained a bachelor's degree in architecture. He was the author of two poetry collections, Driven to Work and No Free Sleeping. He worked in various capacities, practicing and teaching architecture and working as an exhibitions curator at the District Six Museum. He also ran creative workshops, exploring ways to integrate literature and visual art. He participated in many initiatives opposing apartheid and racism over the course of his lifetime. He died in 2022 in South Africa.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, Architecture: University of Cape Town"]

Biography: Freedom Nyamubaya was born in 1958 in Zimbabwe. She was known for being a guerilla fighter during the war for freedom. As a teenager, she cut her secondary school education short to join the Zimbabwe National Liberation Army in Mozambique, where she achieved the rank of Female Field Operation Commander. Later, she became the Secretary for Education in the first ZANU Women’s League conference in 1979. After Independence, she founded an NGO that provides agro-services to rural farmers and was a founding member of the Zimbabwe Peace and Security Trust, promoting peace. She was the author of the poetry collections On The Road Again and Dusk of Dawn.

Biography: Edward Dzonze was born in Zimbabwe. An award-winning poet, he is the author of "Many Truths Told At Once; Wisdom Speaks & Breakfast". With Marechera, he co-edited the Zimbolicious Poetry Series Volume 1 & 2. Dzonze has contributed to more than 15 other anthologies and journals across the globe and is currently working on his fifth poetry collection, Here We Stand.  He has been published in three anthologies to date; world peace anthology (India,2014), we are one (Diaspora Publishers, UK, 2014) and recently in New African Voices (2015 ). His poetry also appeared in numerous E-books, two of which compiled by the society of young Nigerian writers his poetry appears on more than 20 blogs and websites.

Biography: Amitabh Mitra is an Indian-born South African poet and physician. He is the author of several books including A Slow Train to Gwalior, Leaping the Lilac Sun, and Stranger than a Sun. He studied medicine and orthopaedic surgery at the Gajara Raja Medical College in Jiwaji University, in Gwalior, India. He went on to specialize in aerospace medicine and family medicine at the University of Pretoria in South Africa. His work focuses on his physical locations of residence, such as Gwalior where he grew up, and the black township of Mdantsane where he works at the Cecilia Makiwane Hospital.
year_degree_institution: [" Orthopedic Surgery: Jiwaji University, Gajara Raja Medical College", " Aerospace Medicine and Family Medicine: University of Pretoria"]

Biography: Danie Marais was born in 1971 in Kimberley, South Africa. He is the author of the Afrikaans poetry collection In Die Buitenste Ruimte (In the Outermost Space).  He attended the university of Stellenbosch where he graduated with a Bachelor degree. He went on to study teaching at the Carl von Ossietzky Universität in Oldenburg, Germany, where he majored in German, mathematics, and philosophy. His debut collection of poems received the Eugène Marais, Ingrid Jonker, and UJ Debut Prizes. In 2007 he was invited to the Poetry International Festival in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He also participated in Poetry Africa in Durban in 2007. Marais is currently a freelance journalist in Cape Town.

Biography: Haji Gora Haji was born in 1933 in Tumbatu, Zanzibar. He is best known for Kimbunga, his debut poetry collection, published in 1994. He never received a formal education but learned the alphabet from a childhood friend. He attended a madrasa as a child where he studied the Koran. His publications include several books of poems, such as Utenzi wa Visa vya Nabii Suleiman bin Daudi (The Epic of Prophet Suleiman, Son of Daud) and Siri ya Ging’ingi (The Secrets of Ging’ingi), along with five children’s books and a novel.

Biography: Makhosazana Xaba was born in South Africa in 1957. She is the author of several poetry collections including: The Alkalinity of Bottled Water, These Hands, and Tongues of Their Mothers. She trained as a nurse before obtaining a master's degree in creative writing from the University of Witswatersrand. She is now a professor of humanities at the University of Johannesburg. In addition to poetry, she is a short story writer. Her collection of stories, Running and Other Stories, was published in 2013 and won the 2014 Nadine Gordimer South African Literary Awards Short Story Award.

Biography: Mawete Makisosila was born in 1955 in Angola. He is the co-author of Chants Polyphoniques Des Pogroms de Luanda, along with Makuzayi Massaki. He attended the Sorbonne in Paris and the School for Advanced Social Sciences, where he studied information and knowledge systems and anthropology, respectively. His father was active in the revolt against Portuguese rule. Makisosila went on to spend several years in exile in Kinshasa, Congo before returning to Angola to join the MPLA, a political party. He currently lives in France.
year_degree_institution: [" Systemes D'Information et de la Connaissance: Sorbonne Universit\u00e9", " DEA Anthropologie Sociale et Ethnologie: School for Advanced Studies in the Social Sciences"]

Biography: Makuzayi Massaki was born in 1950 in Angola. He is the author of the French language book, Le Conflit Angolais and Chants Polyphoniques Des Pogroms de Luanda. His father was a journalist and founder of the early nationalist party, PDA.  Massaki went into exile to Kinshaha, Congo in the late sixties and spent several years teaching Angolan refugee children before returning to Angola where he joined the military wing of FNLA, a political party. He died in 2003 in France.

Biography: Seitlhamo Motsapi was born in 1966 in Limpopo, South Africa. He is the author of Earthstepper/The Ocean is very Shallow in which he explored his social and political commitment in experimental forms. He attended the University of Witwatersrand where he pursued a Bachelor degree in English and Political Science and the University of Limpopo where he worked on a Bachelor of Arts (Honours) in English Studies. He is a former university lecturer and member of the President's office where he worked as a speechwriter. His work has appeared in numerous global journals and anthologies, including The Heart in Exile, Ten South African Poets, Afrika Afrika, Flora Poetica and A Century of South African Poetry.
year_degree_institution: ["1988 BA, English and Political Science: University of the Witwatersrand", " BA (Honors), English Studies: University of Limpopo"]

Biography: Sim E. Kombem was born in Kom, Cameroon as Emmanuel K. Ngwainmbi. He earned a bachelor's degree in literature from Yaoundé University, a master's degree from Jackson State University, and a doctorate degree from Howard University. He went on to become a professor, the director of International Programs, and a chairperson in the department of language, literature & communication at Elizabeth City State University, North Carolina. He is the author of ten books and has received critical acclaim for his poetry volumes, A Bush of Voices, Shackles on a Ghost Skull, Sim's Poetic Column, and Whispers on My Pillow.
year_degree_institution: [" BA, English and Literature: University of Yaound\u00e9", " MA, English: Jackson State University", "1991 PhD, Communication: Howard University\n"]

Biography: Thierno Seydou Sall is a Senegalese poet. He is the author of six books of poetry in various languages such as French and Wolof. His books primarily explore the rural villages where he has worked for many years with international and local agencies, affirming and challenging local, traditional culture and values. Interested in developing solutions to prevailing problems in his locality, he was a fellow of the prestigious Ashoka Foundation where he worked on creating a modern social communications tool rooted in African culture's deep oral tradition.

Biography: Limam Boicha was born in the Western Sahara in 1972. He is most well known for his Spanish language collection ‘Los versos de la madera.’ Forced to leave his home when he was nine due to the occupation of the Western Sahara region, he went on to study journalism at the Universidad de Oriente in Santiago de Cuba. He returned to the Sahara where he lived in refugee camps before going on to work at the Saharawi National Radio for several years. He later moved back to Spain where he lives and works in Barcelona.
year_degree_institution: [" Journalism: Universidad de Oriente"]

Biography: Isabella Motadinyane was born in 1963 in Soweto, South Africa. She was the author of several books of poetry, including We Jive Like This and Dirty Washing. A book of her collected poems, Bella, was published in 2007. She attended school up to Grade Five. She wrote the poem ‘One Leg In’, which contained the phrase “die is mos botsotsos” (these are stretch denim pants).The phrase gave rise to the name of the Botsotso Jesters, the poetry performance group of which she was a founding member in 1994. The group went on to develop the notable publishing house Botsotso Publishing. Motadinyane died on her fortieth birthday in 2003 in Orange Farm, South Africa.

Biography: Gabeba Baderoon was born in 1969 in Port Elizabeth. A critically acclaimed poet and an academic, she was awarded the Daimler Chrysler Award for South African Poetry for her collection titled The Dream in the Next Body (2005). She has authored other poetry books, which include The Museum of Ordinary Life (2005), A Hundred Silences (2006), The Silence Before Speaking (2005), Cinnamon (2009), and The History of Intimacy (2018). She had B.A. in English and Psychology (University of Cape Town, 1989), M.A. in Postmodernist Television (Media Studies, University of Cape Town), and a PhD. in Media Studies (University of Cape Town, 2004). Her other awards include the 2005 Guest Writer Fellowship at the Nordic Africa Institute, 2008 Civitella Ranieri Fellowship in Italy, 2008: Writer's Residency at the University of Witwatersrand, and the 2019 Meida24 Books Literary Prize: Elizabeth Eybers Prize for The History of Intimacy.

Biography: Ronelda Kamfer was born in 1981 in South Africa. She has written four books of poetry, including Noudat Slapende Honde (Now Then Sleeping Dog), Santenkraam, Mammie and Chinatown. She typically writes in Kaaps-Afrikaans which contains English and South African slang, exploring complex subjects such as rape, humiliation, domestic violence, race, poverty and the position and role of women. She has a masters degree from the University of Western Cape in Afrikaans and Dutch. She is the recipient of the Eugene Marais prize from the South African Academy of Science and Arts, among other prizes.

Biography: Beckett was born in 1955. A British social worker, university lecturer, and science fiction author, he has written several textbooks, dozens of short stories, and six novels. He was educated at the Dragon School in Oxford and Bryanston School in Dorset, England. He has been a senior lecturer in social work at ARU since 2000. He was a social worker for eight years and the manager of a children and families social work team for ten years. Beckett has authored or co-authored several textbooks and scholarly articles on social work.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Bristol\n", " : University of Wales", " : Goldsmith College", " : Anglia Ruskin University, Cambridge"]

Biography: Jofre Rocha is the pen name of Roberto Antônio Victor Francisco de Almeida. He was born in 1941 in what is now the municipality of Icolo e Bengo, Angola. He is most well known as a poet for his first book Tempo de cicio (Time to Whisper), which explores war and the social and economic degradation that emerges from it, and Entre Sonho e Desvario (Between Dream and Madness), which turns to the optimism of national construction and reconstruction, allowing life and dreams to permeate. In 1990, he completed his degree in social sciences in Luanda. He is a founding member of the Angolan Writers Union. Politically imprisoned several times before Angolan independence, De Almeida later served as the President of the National Assembly of Angola from 1996 to 2008. He retired from his political career in 2015.
year_degree_institution: ["1990 Social Sciences: Unknown University"]

Biography: Clinton V du Plessis was born in 1963 in Eastern Cape, South Africa. He is the author of several books of poetry, including Confession of a Hermit, Curriculum Vitae, Words Rust in the Water, and In God's country: no. 2–21. Although he never completed his degree, he attended the University of South Africa. He went on to work as an accountant for many years while writing and publishing books of poetry. To aid up-and-coming writers, in 1987 he founded his own publishing house and literary magazine Akuut. His work has been published in English, Afrikaans, and Spanish.

Biography: Oumarou Watta is a poet, novelist, and scholar from Niger. He is the author of several books of poetry and scholarship. He attended the State University of New York in Buffalo where he received a doctoral degree in 1985, and has since worked as a professor at tertiary institutions.

Biography: ​​Mohamed Metwalli was born in 1970 in Cairo, Egypt. He is most well known for his collections Once Upon a Time, which won the Yussef el-Khal prize awarded by Riadh el-Rayyes Books in Lebanon, and his recent collection A Song by the Aegean Sea, published in 2015. A Song by the Aegean Sea explores Turkey’s Aegean coast from the perspective of a traveler who yearns to become part of the scenes he describes. Metwalli went to University of Cairo for his BA in English Literature. He represented Egypt in the International Writers’ Program at the University of Iowa in 1997, and in 1998 served as the Poet-in-Residence at the University of Chicago. He lives in Cairo.

Biography: Hoda Hussein is a poet, painter, and translator born in Cairo in 1972. She is the author of six books of poetry, two novels, and five book-length translation works, in addition to numerous publications in magazines and newspapers. Her work has notably appeared in two anthologies, in The Poetry of Arab Women and in Angry Voices: An Anthology of the Off-Beat New Egyptian Poets. She is also a visual artist.  Her paintings have appeared at the Ghandi Institute in Ambala, India, among other places.

Biography: Mahmoud Sharaf was born in Egypt. He graduated from Tanta University in Egypt in 1996. He has published several books of poetry, and is most well known for his collection Howwat Tabi'eya. His work has been published in Angry Voices: An Anthology of Off-beat New Egyptian Poets, Al-Qahirah, and Al-Kitaba al-Ohkra, among other publications. He is a journalist at Sout Al Arab radio station and the Nile Culture Channel. He also facilitates the annual Tanta International Festival.

Biography: Youssef Rakha was born in 1976 in Cairo, Egypt. He obtained a bachelor's and master's degrees from Hull University, and went on to work as a journalist for Al-Ahram Weekly. He is the author of several books of poetry and has been selected as one of the best Arab writers under 40. He writes in English and Arabic and his work has been translated into Italian, French, German, Spanish, and Polish. His work is concerned with the role of obscenity in Arab society and the post-Muslim perspective. He co-founded the English language paper The National in Abu Dhabi in 2007.
year_degree_institution: ["1998 BA, English and Philosophy: University of Hull"]

Biography: Hamid Tibouchi was born in 1951 in Tibane, Algeria.  He studied fine arts at the University of Paris VIII, and graduated in 1983. He worked as a French language assistant and English teacher before devoting himself to writing and producing works of visual arts. He is the author of over a dozen books of French language poems, including Mer Ouverte and Soleil d'herbe. As a visual artist, he has exhibited around sixty solo shows and nearly three hundred group exhibitions, in France and around the world.

Biography: Maher Sabry was born in 1967, in Cairo, Egypt. Mostly well known as a poet for his publications in various journals and anthologies, and for his collection Marionnette, he is also a playwright, graphic designer, and filmmaker. His poems explore sexuality and queer existence in Egyptian society. Sabry is also an LGBTQ activist, well known for his coverage of the notorious Queen Boat arrests in 2001 in Cairo, for which he was awarded the Felipa de Souza Award in 2002. He attended Cairo University and received a bachelor of arts degree in English, and studied cinema in San Francisco after seeking asylum in the U.S. He went on to a career in film and theater.
year_degree_institution: ["1993 BA, English: Cairo University"]

Biography: Pinkie Mekgwe was born in Botswana. She went to the University of Botswana where she received a Bachelor of Arts. She went on to obtain a Master's degree in Critical Theory and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in Gender and Literary Studies at the University of Sussex. In addition to writing poetry, she has served as an assistant lecturer at Sussex University’s School of African and Asian Studies, and a visiting lecturer at Malmo University in Sweden. She has also worked in international development in various contexts and as a producer and presenter of “Open Book,” an educational, literature-focused radio programme aired on a Gaborone-based radio station.
year_degree_institution: [" BA: University of Botswana", " MA, Critical Theory: University of Sussex", " PhD, Gender and Literary Studies: University of Sussex"]

Biography: Ike Mboneni Muila was born 1955 in Soweto, South Africa. He is most well known for his work with the poetry performance group, the Botsotso Jesters, with whom he has published recordings and performed at festivals. Between 1988 and 1990, Muila performed with the Madimba music students at the Soyinkwa Institute of African Theatre in Soweto. His recent solo collection, GOVA, includes drawings as well as recordings, and reflects the multilingual, many-faceted life of South Africa. Muila continued as a performance poet with the Botsotso Jesters, and serves as Board Chair of Botsotso Publishing, a publishing, dramatic arts, literary management, and activist organization of which he was a founding member.

Biography: Joao Pedro was born in Namibia in 1948. He lived in Luanda, the capital of Angola, for several years and  worked in the Ministry of Development. He is the author of Ponto de Situação, a book of poems in Portugese informed by his experience with the Angolan Liberation war. A selection of his poems was also published in The New African Poetry: An Anthology, edited by Tanure Ojaide.
(CAP) Bio Sources (MLA): Ojaide, Tanure. New African Poetry: An Anthology. Washington: Three Continents Press, 1999.

Biography: Mbuyiseni Oswald Mtshali was born in 1940 in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. He is the author of several poetry collections including Sounds of a Cowhide Drum and Fireflames. After apartheid legislation prevented him from studying, he obtained a diploma from the Premier School of Journalism and Authorship, affiliated with London University. He went on to receive an undergraduate degree in the New School of Social Research, an MFA from Columbia University, and a Doctor of Philosophy from Columbia University. He went on to teach at the New York City College of Technology until his return to South Africa in 2007.
year_degree_institution: [" : London University, Premier School of Journalism and Authorship", " BA from School of Social Research: The New School", " MFA: Columbia University", "1998 PhD: Columbia University"]

Biography: Ingrid de Kok was born 1951 in Johannesburg, South Africa. She is most well known for her collections Familiar Ground, Transfer and Terrestrial Things, where she explores the possibilities of shaping the future by dealing with the past and considering the present.. She went to university of University of Witwatersrand for her undergrad in English and Political Science. She also received a Bachelor Honors with honors from the University of Cape Town and a masters at Queen’s University. She continued on to become an Associate Professor at the at the Centre for Extra-Mural Studies, University of Cape Town in South Africa.

Biography: Mutombo Nkulu-N’Sengha was born in the Democratic Republic of Congo. He is the author of Bela-Wenda, a book of poetry. He attended Major Seminar St. Paul where he obtained an undergraduate degree in Philosophy and Theology. He went on to receive two Master's degrees and a PhD. He currently teaches African religions, American religious diversity, and comparative religions at California State University. He also serves as the editor of the Congo Times. In addition to poetry, he has written extensively on Bumuntu philosophy.
year_degree_institution: ["1981 BA: Major Seminary St. Paul", "1989 MA: Institute P. Canisius Kinshasa", "1991 MA: Gregorian University", "1996 MA: Temple University", "2002 PhD: Temple University"]
