Biography: Alain Mabanckou was born in Republic of the Congo and grew up in Pointe Noire. A novelist, poet, and academic, Mabanckou is one of the most recognized writers in French contemporary literature. His published poetry collections include Quand le coq annoncera l'aube d'un autre jour (1999), Au jour le jour (1993), L'usure des lendemains (1995), and Les arbres aussi versent des larmes (1997). He has received many awards for his writing, including the 2017 Man Booker International Prize for his novel, Black Moses, and the 2012 Académie Française Grand Prix de littérature Henri Gal for his entire work. He teaches literature and creative writing in the Department of French & Francophone Studies and African Studies Center at University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).

Biography: Maged Zaher was born in Cairo, Egypt. He is the author of several books of poetry including Opting Out: Early, New & Collected Poems; The Consequences of My Body; and If Reality Doesn’t Work Out. He has two master's degrees in computer engineering and computer science from the University of Akron and Cairo university. He worked as a software engineer for thirty years. Since 1995, he has lived and worked, producing literary work. He is the recipient of numerous awards such as the Genius Award for Literature from The Stranger.
year_degree_institution: ["1997 MS. Computer Science: University of Akron", "1995 MS, Computer Aided Engineering: Cairo University"]

Biography: Ignatius Mabasa was born 1971 in Mount Darwin, Zimbabwe. He has written two books of poetry in Shona—a Tipeiwo Dariro and Muchinokoro Kunaka— along with three novels and two children’s books. He studied Shona and Linguistics in University of Zimbabwe. He also received his masters and PhD at University of Oslo and Rhodes University. He went on to become a professor at University of Zimbabwe. He founded Bhabhu Books, a publishing company for Shona, Ndebele, and other vernacular language novels, stories novels and stories.

Biography: Tomé Varela da Silva was born in 1948 in Cape Verde. A poet, scholar, and philosopher, he is the author of several books in which he explored the oral tradition and the musical heritage of Cape Verde. Na Bóka Noti, his seminal four-part series, captured the changes the Cape Verdean language underwent over the course of three decades. The first volume was written in the alphabet proposed at the Mindelo Colloquium in 1979, whereas the fourth volume appeared in Alfabétu Kauberdianu, the alphabet style instituted by the government in 2009. He is regarded as one of the most important Cape Verdean poets of his time.

Biography: Ishmael Fiifi Annobil was born in Accra, Ghana in 1958. A musician, journalist, filmmaker, poet, and critic, he is the author of Seven Horn Elegy (Totem, 1998) and Ethiop (Totem); his work has been anthologized in Another English: Anglophone Poems from Around the World. He is also the founder of the Welsh poetry festival Iolo’s Children, and the founding editor of the literary magazine Chiaroscuro. Currently, Annobil lives in London.

Biography: Juliana Makuchi Nfah-Abbenyi was born in 1958 in the South-West Province of Cameroon and raised in North West Province. Writer and critic, she is the author of Our Madness, Not Mine: Stories of Cameroon (1999), The Sacred Door and Other Stories: Cameroon Folktales of the Beba (2008), among others. In her work, she offers a complex exploration of African stereotypes, gender inequalities grounded in cultural and political contexts and a critique of the postcolonial Cameroonian identity. She received her B.A. in Bilingual Letters, English & French and MA in African Literature from the University of Yaounde. She also holds a doctorate in Comparative Literature from McGill University in Montreal, Canada, after which she immigrated to the United States. From 2012-2018, she served on the Executive Council of the African Literature Association (ALA). She is Distinguished Professor of English and Comparative Literature in the Department of English at North Carolina State University.

Biography: Margaret Afuh Mbah was born in Cameroon. She is the author of four books in English, including Born Before Her Time, Fireside Stories, Flowers in the Desert, and Echoes Across Time which explore issues endemic to local Cameroonian society such as poverty and mass emigration. In addition to writing, she teaches literature and the English language at a local high school.

Biography: Lesego Rampolokeng was born in 1965 in Orlando West, Soweto, Johannesburg. A poet, novelist, playwright, and filmmaker, he is the author of collections of poetry including Talking Rain (1993), The Bavino Sermons (1999), Head on Fire (2012) and A Half Century Thing (2015). He also authored three novels, two plays, screenplays and has collaborated in performances and recording with several musicians. He studied law at the University of the North in South Africa.

Biography: Chehem Watta was born in Djibouti in 1962. He is the author of several French language collections of poetry including: Pèlerin d’errance (Wandering Pilgrim), Sur les soleils de Houroud (On the Suns of Houroud) and Rimbaud l’Africain (Rimbaud the African). He studied ethnopsychiatry in France, obtaining a doctorate degree, before returning to Djibouti where he became a senior civil servant and teacher. He has since held several high-profile positions, such as being the HIV/AIDS advisor to the president of the Djibouti Republic and the secretary general of the School of Medicine. His poetry celebrates the land and the landscapes, nomadic life, the desert and its rigors, and the drama of his people who were torn apart by the brutal arrival of the modern world.
year_degree_institution: [" PhD, Ethnopsychiatry: Unknown University"]

Biography: Frank Mkalawile  Chipasula was born in 1949 in Luanshya, Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia). A notable voice in African literature, Chipasula is the author of critically acclaimed poetry collections such as Visions and Reflections (1972),  A Decade in Poetry (1980), O Earth, Wait for Me (1984),  Nightwatcher, Nightsong (1986), When My Brothers Come Home: Poems from Central and Southern Africa, Middletown (1985), Whispers in the Wings (1991), and others. Chipasula attended Universities of Zambia, Brown, and Yale for his degrees in Creative Writing, African American Literature and English Literature. His awards and nominations include the BBC Poetry Prize, Pushcart Prize, Fulbright travel grant (1978-80), Noma award honorable mention, African Book Publishing Record (1985), etc.

Biography: Nyachiro Lydia Kasese is a Tanzanian writer, poet, and media specialist. She is the author of the chapbook “Paper Dolls,” included in (TATU) New-Generation African Poets: A Chapbook Box Set. Her poem “Things That Were Lost In Our Vaginas” was shortlisted by the BNPA poetry prize in 2014, and her short story “Inside Outside” was long-listed by Writivism in the same year. In 2017, her short story “My Mother’s Project” was published in the Caine Prize 2017 Anthology.
year_degree_institution: ["2013 BA, Industrial and Economic Sociology: Rhodes University"]

Biography: John Ngong Kum Ngong was born in Esu, Menchum, Cameroon. He attended Cameroon Protestant College Bali, Bilingual Grammar School Molyko in Buea, and the University of Yaoundé. He holds a master's degree in African Literature and a Certificate in Reading in a Foreign Language from the University of Birmingham. He is the author of two books of poetry, Walls of Agony and Chants of a Lunatic. He currently works as the principal of a high school.

Biography: Samira Negrouche was born in Algeria in 1980. Trained as a doctor, she has gone on to author several poetry collections, including Quai 2I1, Partition à Trois Axes, Six Arbres de Fortune Autour de ma Baignoire, Le Jazz des Oliviers, and A l'ombre de Grenade. She works as a translator from Arabic and English to French as well. Her own work has been translated to over twenty languages.

Biography: Phillip Zhuwao was born in 1971 in Harare, Zimbabwe. He was the son of a Mozambican mother and a Zambian father, born on a commercial farm into conditions of poverty. These origins were apparent in his writing, as he wrote in English but used neologisms, deliberate misspellings, and slang from rural communities. These varied registers and dialects make his work both fresh and unique. He died of an illness in 1994 at the tender age of 23. In the early 1990s, his poems were published in the South African journals Bliksem and New Coin. In 2004, a selection of his poems was collected and edited by Robert Berold and published by the South African publisher Deep South under the title Sunrise Poison. This edition contains the one surviving interview with Zhuwao.

Biography: Hassan Najmi was born in 1959 in Ben Ahmed, Morocco. He is the author of several poetry collections, including Lavenders’ Princedom, Fallen Inadvertently, and Brown Winds, all of which are characterized by an interest in everyday life. Although his earlier poetry followed the traditions of Moroccan pioneer poets such as Ahmed Mejjati, Mohammed Serghini, and Abdelkarim Tabbal, he later departed from this style in favour of a more contemporary position. His poetry has been translated into English by Roger Allen, a renowned translator of modern Arabic fiction.

Biography: Loftus Marais was born in Paarl, Cape Town in 1982. His debut poetry collection, Staan in die algemeen nader aan vensters (2008), won four literary prizes: the Eugene Marais Prize, The University of Johannesburg Debut Prize, The Ingrid Jonker Prize and the Protea Prize. His other publications include Kry my by die gewone plek aguur (2012) and Jan, Piet, Koos en Jakob : gedigte (2019). His poems offer reflections on Cape Town and bring into sharper focus the many facets of his birthplace. He received his BA in Afrikaans-Dutch and MA in Creative Afrikaans Writing from the University of Stellenbosch. Marais lives in Cape Town and works as a freelance journalist.

Biography: Albert G.T.K. Malikongwa was born in 1930 in Mayebe Nswazwi, Botswana.  He is the author of the poetry collection The Smell of Cowdung and the play Chief Mengwe IV. He attended St. Joseph’s College and Roma College, and later received a degree in public administration from the University of York. He worked as a teacher for several years before continuing on to work for the government, retiring as a member of the Customary Court of Appeal. He received the Presidential Award for Meritorious Service in 1999 from former president of Botswana, Festus Mogae.

Biography: Frida Menkan Mbunda-Nekang was born in Oku sub-division of the North West Region of Cameroon. She is the author of a book of poetry, Shadows from the Abyss, along with other plays and scholarly publications. She went to the University of Yaounde for her undergrad in English. She also received a Master's and a Doctor of Philosophy degrees at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka. She taught at the universities of Kogi State and Nsukka in Nigeria, and currently teaches at the University of Buea in Cameroon.

Biography: Jared Angira was born in 1947 in Siaya, Kenya. Critically praised and recognized as a Marxist poet, Angira is the author of poetry collections such as Juices (1970), Silent Voices (1972), Cascades (1976), The Years Go By (1980), Soft Corals (1973). Tides of Time: Selected Poems (1996), and Lament of the Silent and Other Poems (2004). Angira attended the University of Nairobi, where he studied Commerce between 1968-1971. Aside being a poet, he also worked in the Kenyan Civil Service. He once said that Karl Marx is his teacher, while Pablo Neruda is his class prefect (in class) and his captain (on the battlefield).

Biography: Amatoritsero Ede was born in Nigeria in 1963. A teacher and an award-winning poet, Ede is the author of A Writer’s Pains & Caribbean Blues, his first poetry collection, which won the 1998 All Africa Okigbo Prize for Literature. His other collections are Globetrotter & Hitler’s Children (2009) and Teardrops on the Weser (2021). Ede attended Leibniz University, Hannover, Germany (BA and MA), and Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada (PhD), where he was the 2005–2006 Writer-in-Residence. He is the publisher and managing editor of Maple Tree Literary Supplement.

Biography: Ahmad Al Shahawi was born in 1960 in Damietta, Egypt. He attended Assiut University where he studied journalism. He went on to work at Al-Ahram newspaper before becoming the editor-in-chief of the weekly magazine "Nisf Al-Dunya." He is the author of several poetry collections including: wo Rak'at for Love, Book of Death and Say That It Is Her. He won the UNESCO Prize in Literature in 1995 and the Cavafy Poetry Prize in 1998. His work has been translated into many languages including English, Dutch, French, Spanish, and Turkish.
year_degree_institution: ["1983 BA, Journalism: Assiut University"]

Biography: Hassan El Ouazzani was born in 1950 in Morocco. He is the author of several poetry collections, including: Hudnatun ma (A Truce), Répertoire des écrivains marocains,and La production littéraire marocaine 1929–1999: Bio-bibliographie et étude socio-bibliométrique. He has a master's degree in in Library Science, Archiving, and Libraries, and a doctorate in literature.  He teaches and researches at the School of Information Sciences in Rabat. He is known for being a member of the generation of poets who, in the 1990s, brought the prose-poem into prominence in Moroccan poetry. The generation included seminal poets such as Jalal El Hakmaoui, Mahmoud Abdelghani, Abdelilah Salhi, and Yassin Adnan.

Biography: Alan Finlay is a writer, researcher and editor from Johannesburg. He is the author of poetry collections which include "Burning Aloes" (Dye Hard Press, 1994), "No Free Sleeping" with Donald Parenzee and Vonani Bila (Botsotso Publishing, 1998), "The Red Laughter of Guns in Green Summer Rain" – chainpoems with Philip Zhuwao (Dye Hard Press, 2002), and "pushing from the bank (Dye Bank, 2010). In 1994, with Robert Berold, he co-edited a collection of Eastern Cape school poetry called Parking Space (Institute for the Study of English in Africa). He has also co-edited a collection of new South African prose and poetry with Arja Salafranca called glass jars among trees (Jacana, 2003). Alan’s recent collection, pushing from the riverbank, was published by Dye Hard Press in 2010. He teaches communications for social change at the Wits University Journalism Programme.

Biography: Bongekile Joyce Mbanjwa was born 1962 in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa. She is most well known for her collection Emotional Pain (Izinhlungu Zomphefumulo) published in Zulu and English. She attended the South African Council for Social Service Professions, University of Natal, KwaZulu-Natal Sign Language Academy and UNISA. She continued on to become a social services worker. Her stories and poems have been published in various venues, including Botsotso 13 and the anthology of women’s poetry and photography, Isis X.

Biography: Ouidad Benmoussa was born 1969 in Ksar el-Kebir, northwestern Morocco. Her poetry collections include li jidrun fil-hawa' (I have a Root in The Air, 2001), bayna ghamamatayn (Between Two Clouds, 2003), among others. In "A Storm in a Body," the writer explores themes of desire, womanhood and sexuality and she is also known to draw on personal experiences as a tool of self-exploration and artistic freedom. She was vice president of the House of Contemporary Art in Asilah and also worked as counselor at the office of the Minister of Moroccan Culture. Benmoussa is a member of the Board of the House of Poetry in Morocco and works as a journalist at Moroccan news channel M24.

Biography: Emad Fouad was born in Alfaroniya village in the Nile Delta of Egypt in 1974. He has published several collections of poetry, including This is the Language of the Lucky Preys, Ten Ways to Maim a Dead Body, and Silk. He studied journalism at the University of Cairo and went on to work as a freelance journalist for numerous Arabic newspapers and magazines. His poetry has been translated into several languages, among which are English, French, Dutch, Persian, German, Polish, Romanian, Spanish, Latvian and Russian. He has been living in Antwerp, Belgium since 2004, but he writes only in his native tongue, Arabic.

Biography: Zolani Mkiva was born in 1974 in Eastern Cape, South Africa. He went to the University of the Western Cape where he obtained an undergraduate degree in Social Science, followed by another in Development Studies. In 1990, he served as a young imbongi, praise singer, at a welcome home rally for former President Nelson Mandela and went on to become Imbongi Yesizwe, Poet to the Nation. He was later also the praise singer at Nelson Mandela’s Presidential inauguration in 1994, and subsequently became the President’s Poet Laureate. He is currently a member of the South African parliament.
year_degree_institution: [" BA (Honors), Development Studies: University of the Western Cape\n"]

Biography: Peter Wuteh Vakunta is a native of Bamunka-Ndop in the Northwest Region of the Republic of Cameroon. He earned Bachelor's degrees in Cameroon and Nigeria, as well as MA and MS degrees in the US and Cameroon. He earned his Ph.D. in French and Francophone Studies with a minor in linguistics from the University of Wisconsin Madison. He is the author of poetry collections such as Bearing Witness (2020, Spears Media Press, Cameroon),  Straddling the Mungo: A Book of Poems in English and French (2009. Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), Green Rape: Poetry for the Environment (2008. Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), Poems from Abakwa in Cameroon Pidgin English (2015, Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), Takembeng and other Poems from Abakwa (2015, Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), Requiem pour Ongola en camfranglais: une poetique camerounaise (2015, Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), Martryrdom and Other Freedom Poems (2010, Langaa RPCIG, Cameroon), and other collections. He is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Modern Languages in the United States of America.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Wisconsin-Madison"]

Biography: Ngudia Wendel was born in 1940 in the Icolo e Bengo region of Angola. He worked with the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola as a guerilla leader, and after training in the Soviet Union, he transitioned into a role as a doctor. Between 1973-1974, he was Director of Medical Services on the Northern Front and in Cabinda. His collection Nos Volteramos, Luanda! (We Shall Return Luanda!) was published in Lusaka in 1973 and in a bilingual Portuguese—Italian edition at Forli in 1976.

Biography: Mourad Djebel was born in Annaba, Algeria in 1967. He studied town planning at the Mentouri University in Constantine, Algeria. Attracted to West Africa by the authors he admired, such as the Congolese author Tchicaya U'Tamsi, he travelled the continent, then, in 1994, settled in France. Although his work is written in French, he draws heavily from North African oral tradition which he incorporates by mixing universal heroes, moral themes, contemporary incursions, and mischievous humor. He is the author of several books such as Les Sens Prohibited and Les Contes des Trois Rives.

Biography: Mafika Pascal Gwala was born 1946 in Verulam, South Africa. He is most well known for his involvement in the anti-apartheid and Black Consciousness movement. He is the author of two poetry collections: Jol'iinkomo (1977) and No More Lullabies (1982). His poetry was informed by the socio-political conditions and injustice of South Africa and articulated a call to resistance. He went to the University of Natal for his M.Phil. in Politics. Poet and editor, he was a founding member of the Mpumalanga Arts Ensemble based in Hammarsdale. In 2007, Gwala received The SALA Literary Lifetime Award. He passed away on 6 September 2014 in Mpumalanga, South Africa.

Biography: Juliane Okot Bitek was born in 1966 in Kenya. An assistant professor of Black Creativity at Queen’s University in Kingston, Otoniya was awarded the 2017 Glenna Luschei Prize for African Poetry for her book titled 100 Days (2016) that explores the monumental tragedy of 1994 Rwandan genocide. Juliane is also the author of books that include Words in Black Cinnamon (1988), Sublime: Lost Words (2018, The Elephants), Gauntlet (2019, Nomados, Vancouver, British Columbia). Her book 100 Days has also been awarded prizes such as the 2017 Alberta Book Awards, 2017 BC Book Prize, the Pat Lowther Award, the 2017 Canadian Authors Award for Poetry.

Biography: Lionel Abrahams was born in 1928 in Johannesburg, South Africa. A poet, novelist and essayist, Abrahams is most well known for his poetry. He published five collections of poems, including Journal of a New Man (1984), The Writer in Sand (1988), A Dead Tree Full of Live Birds (1988), and Chaos Theory of the Heart (2005). Abrahams attended Damelin College and Wits University, both located in South Africa. In 2004, he died in Johannesburg.

Biography: Kwadwo Opoku-Agyemang was born in 1952 in Kwabeng, Ghana. His two poetry collections are Cape Coast Castle (1996) and Wise Eyes: The Anomabo Poems, which was the Winner of the 2018 Peter Tillou-Venture Smith Book Prize. In Cape Coast Castle, the poet explores one of three slave castles on the coast of Ghana, chattel slavery, and the trauma of the trans-Atlantic slave trade. In 1975, he received his B.A. Hons., Dip.Ed. in Education from University of Cape Coast, Ghana. He also went to York University, Canada for his undergraduate and doctorate studies. Opoku-Agyemang is a Professor of Literature at University of Cape Coast, Ghana.
year_degree_institution: [" : York University", " : York University", " : University of Cape Coast"]

Biography: Kwesi Brew was born in 1928 in Cape Coast, Ghana. A writer and a diplomat, he is the author of critically acclaimed poetry collections such as The Shadows of Laughter (1968), African Panorama and Other Poems (Greenfield Center, New York, 1981), Return of No Return and other poems (1995), The Clan of the Leopard and other poems (1996). He attended the University College of the Gold Coast (now Ghana) and earned a degree in English in 1953. The winner of a British Council Poetry Competition in Accra, Brew’s work has been published in many anthologies across the world.

Biography: Abena Busia was born 1953 in Accra, Ghana. Her published works include Testimonies of Exile (1990) and Traces of a Life: A Collection of Elegies and Praise Poems (2008). She went to St Anne's College in Oxford for her bachelors in English language and Literature and received her D.Phil. in Social Anthropology from St. Antony's College. As a scholar, her research focuses on gender, race, multi-cultural, and African diaspora studies and she is the co-director and co-editor of the Women Writing Africa Project, a multi-volume anthology presenting African Women’s voices and examining cultural and historical contexts of their writings. In 2017, she was appointed Ghana's ambassador to Brazil. She was a Professor of English at Rutgers University for forty years until her retirement in 2021.

Biography: Mustapha Benfodil was born in 1968 in Relizane, Algeria. A playwright, novelist, and poet, he is well known for representing contemporary revolutionary Algerian writing and activism. His poem "To the health of the Republic!," which was written in tribute to assassinated writer Tahar Djaout, earned him the Special Jury Prize at the 5th Poésiades de Béjaïa in 1993. His other works include Kafkain Cocktail: Black Poetry and Pales vénustés de barracks, written during his military service in Sidi Bel Abbès and Djelfa. He went to the University of Sciences and Technology Houari Boumediiène for his Maths baccalaureate in 1987. With provocative and transgressive humor, he creates work that examines the political tension and economic crisis of his country. Benfodil is a journalist at El Watan and was awarded the Mohammed-Dib 2020 prize, which rewards authors writing in Arabic, Amazigh, and French.

Biography: Bate Besong was born in 1954 in Mamfe (Manyu Division), Cameroon. Among his collections of poetry are The Grains of Bobe Ngom Jua (1986), Obasinjom Warrior with Poems after Detention (1991) and Disgrace: Autobiographical Narcissus and Emanya-nkpe (2007). He went to the University of Calabar in Nigeria for his Masters and later received his PhD in Literary Studies from the same university. As a playwright and poet, he is widely known for his stance on art as a political fighting tool and his writings as a way to indict and criticize corrupt governance. He faced persecution as a result of his militant activism and was kidnapped and released in 1992. In 1992, he won the Association of Nigerian Authors' Prize for his Cameroonian drama, Requiem for the Last Kaiser. He was a lecturer at the University of Buea from 1999 until his death in 2007.

Name Built: de Carvalho, Ruy Duarte 'Ruy Alberto Duarte Gomes de Carvalho'
Biography: Ruy Duarte de Carvalho was born 1941 in Santarém, Portugal and grew up in Namibe, south of Angola. His writings captured experiences of the Kuvale people of southern Angola, including their nomadic pastoral way of life and traditions. Poet, film director, and anthropologist, he was actively involved in Angola’s freedom fight. He received his diploma and doctorate from the School of High Studies in Social Sciences, Paris in 1982 and 1986 respectively. Considered one of Angola’s most prestigious poets, he devoted himself to the study of photography and traditional oral poetry. He taught at Luanda, Coimbra, Sao Paulo, Paris and Berkely until he moved to Swakopmund, Namibia where he died in 2010.

Biography: Emmanuel Fru Doh was born 1960 in British Southern Cameroon. His first poetry collection, Not Yet Damascus was published in 2007. He’s also the author of Oriki’badan (2009) and Shadows (2011). His work is known to address the socio-political state of affairs on the African continent and also draw attention to the exploitation and control of Cameroon under imperialism. He went to The University of Ibadan, Nigeria for his BA (Hons) English (1984), M.A. English- Lit. emphasis (1987) and Ph.D. in English (1990). Fru Doh currently teaches in the Department of English at Century College, Minnesota, U.S.A. where he is also Associate Editor of Phantasmagora.

Biography: Mbella Sonne Dipoko was born in 1936 in Douala, Cameroon. He is the author of the poetry collection Black and White in Love (1972). His literary portfolio consists of writings grounded in militant ideals as well as overt sexuality; the latter has received both praise and criticism for its eroticism. A poet and novelist, he went to University of Paris for his studies in Law and Economics, but decided to pursue writing full time. Considered one of the foremost writers of Anglophone Cameroonian literature, Dipoko’s work has been widely anthologized. He returned from the West in 1985 and in 1991 and was enthroned as the chief of Misaka, a position previously held by his late father. He died in 2009 in Tiko, Cameroon.

Biography: Bole Butake was born in 1947 in Nkor Noni, North West Province of Cameroon. Poet and playwright, he is well known for the agitprop nature of his work and writing on issues of corruption and governance, as well as his contribution to the arts and culture in Cameroon. He received his BA in Modern English Letters from the University of Yaounde and his MA in English Literature from the University of Leeds. He also earned his PhD in 1983 from the Faculty of Letters and Social Sciences, University of Yaoundé. Butake continued on to become a professor of Performing Arts and African Literature at University of Yaounde until he retired in 2012. He died in 2016 in Yaounde, Central Province, Cameroon.

Biography: Alain Lawo-Sukam was born in 1973 in Bangwa, Cameroon. Scholar and creative writer, he is the author of trilingual poetry book, Sueño con África/ Dream of Africa/ Rêve d'Afrique (2013). His work examines African experiences in the Hispanic Atlantic world. In 2005, he earned a Ph.D. in Spanish from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He also received his B.Sc and MA from University of Yaounde I in 1995 and 1997 respectively. Lawo-Sukam is an Associate Professor of Hispanic and Africana Studies and the Coordinator of Africana Studies program at Texas A&M University.

Biography: Kangsen Feka Wakai was born 1978 in Bamenda, Cameroon. He is the author of two poetry collections: Fragmented Melodies (2007) and Asphalt Effect (2007). His work explores themes of displacement, injustice, immigration and socio-political conditions of postcolonial Africa. In 2008, he earned his BA in Journalism from Texas Southern University. He also went to American University, Washington, D.C. for his MFA in Creative Writing. A journalist and writer, Wakai has also worked as editor with Tiger Spirit Magazine and as a reporter for TSU Herald and The Monitor Newspaper.

Biography: Lokangaka Losambe was born in 1952 in Omutumba, Kasaï, Zaïre. Several of his poems have been published in Tyume Fort Hare Journal of Creative Writing. He attended National University of Zaire for his BA and MA in English language and literature. He also earned his M.Ed. from the University of Wales in 1979 and his PhD in African Literature from the University of Ibadan in 1983. Losambe’s research interests include African-Anglophone literature, Pan-African literature, Black Atlantic literature, and Post-colonialism. He is a Professor of English at the University of Vermont.

Biography: Syl Cheney-Coker was born in 1945 in Freetown, Seirra Leone. A poet and a novelist, Cheney was awarded the 1991 Commonwealth Writers Prize (Africa Region) for his novel titled The Last Harmattan of Alusine Dunbar (1990). He is the author of critically acclaimed poetry collections such as Concerto for an Exile (1973), The Blood in the Desert’s Eyes (1990),  The Graveyard Also Has Teeth (1974; revised edition, 1979), Stone Child and other poems (2008) and The Road to Jamica: Elegy for the Afro (2015). He attended the University of Oregon (1967-1970), University of California—Los Angeles (1970), and the University of Wisconsin—Madison (1971-72). He received the Fonlon-Nichols Award from the African Literature Association, and a fellowship from the International Writing program at the University of Iowa.

Biography: Safaa Fathy was born in 1958 in Minya, Egypt. She studied English Literature at the University of Minia and moved to Paris in 1981 where she obtained a PhD from Sorbonne. She has written several books of poetry, including Revolution Goes Through Walls written in the wake of the 2011 Egyptian revolution and A Name to the Sea. Her films include Mohammad Saved from the Waters, a film poem titled Nom à la mer and Derrida’s Elsewhere about the famous philosopher Jacques Derrida with whom she collaborated frequently and shared a close relationship

Biography: Pauline Kaldas was born in 1961 in Egypt. She is most well known for her collection Egyptian Compass which explores the personal and historic events that circulate between Egypt and the United States, and between Arabic and English. She went to Clark University for her undergrad in English and Business. She also received her masters in English at the University of Michigan and her Ph.D. in English and Creative Writing at Binghamton University. She continued on to become a professor at the Rhode Island University, American University in Cairo and university of Hollins.

Biography: Kola Boof was born in 1969 in Omdurman, Sudan. After her adoption in 1979, she relocated to Washington, D.C where she was a Psychiatric Out-Patient until she was 17. Novelist and poet, she is the author of the poetry collection “Every Little Bit Hurts” (1995), which has been regarded as a provocative work of art for its political and sexual connotations. Her work is known to explore religion, the sexuality of African women, the treatment of women in Islamic countries, and Sudanese cultural history. Her essay “I Am My Own Daughter” won the Swedish Woman to Woman Literary Award in 2007. Over the years, there have been controversies surrounding her involvement in international politics and diplomatic relations, and Boof’s writings have served as ways of activism and a means to render her own account.

Biography: Peter E. Omoko (Ph.D) is an award-winning playwright/scholar who teaches African oral literature, creative writing, African and European literatures at the Department of English, Delta State College of Education, Mosogar Delta State. Some of his published plays include Battles of Pleasure (2009), Three Plays (an anthology of plays, 2010), Uloho (2013), Crude Nightmen (2015) and Majestic Revolt (2016), Herding South (2019, Malthouse).

Biography: Marjorie Phyllis Oludhe Macgoye was born 1928 in Southhampton, England. She wrote two poetry collections: Song of Nyarloka and Other Poems, a ballad about a young girl’s exploitation and Make It Sing and Other Poems, inspired by Stephen Mathenge, one of the military commanders of the fight against British colonialism. She went to Royal Holloway College, University of London for her undergrad in English. She also received a masters at Birkbeck, University of London in English. She moved to Kenya in 1954 to sell books and became a citizen in 1964. She died in 2015 in Nairobi, Kenya.

Biography: Juan Balboa Boneke was born in 1938 in Rebola, Equatorial Guinea. Writer and politician, he is the author of Sueños en mi selva: Antología poética (Dreams in My Jungle, 1987), O’Boriba (el exiliado) (O’Boriba [The Exiled], 1982), Requiebros (Flirtations, 1994), among others. He served as Minister under the presidency of Teodoro Obiang Nguema until he was forced to leave under the regimes of both Marcaís and Obiang. He went into exile in Palma de Mallorca and the theme of exile was central in his work. Boneke’s writing has also been regarded as political, with the writer advocating for the freedom to criticize dictatorship, corruption, and violence in his country with the hope to build a better nation. He obtained a Social degree from the University from Granada (Spain). In 2014, he died in Valencia, Spain.

Biography: Juan Tomás Ávila Laurel was born November 6th, 1966 in Equatorial Guinea. He has written several books of poetry, novels and short story collections in Spanish. He is most known for his novel By Night Mountains Burn, the second ever Equitoguniean book to be translated into English. His books of poetry include Historia Intima De La Humanidad (Intimate History of Humanity) among others. In 2011, he went on a much publicized hunger strike to protest the political dictatorship of Teodoro Obiang’s. Subsequently, he fled to Spain to escape persecution, where he continues to live, write and teach.

Biography: Liyou Libsekal was born in 1990 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Poet and essayist, she is the author of chapbook, Bearing Heavy Things (2015), part of the African Poetry Book Fund’s New Generation African Poets series. Her poems explore themes of displacement, culture, home, and identity. She also writes about the influences of modernization and globalization on Ethiopia’s economic growth and transformation. In 2014, Libsekal won the Brunel University African Poetry Prize for her poem “Riding Chinese Machines.” She earned her BA in Anthropology from George Washington University. She lives in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

Biography:
Kofi Anyidoho is a Ghanian poet and professor, born in 1947. He went to the University of Ghana in 1973 where he received a BA in English and Linguistics. His books of poetry include Elegy for the Revolution (1978), A Harvest of Our Dreams (1985), Earthchild (1985), and Ancestral Logic and Caribbean Blues (1992).

Biography: Ladé Wosornu was born 1937 in Galo-Sota, located in South Tongu District in the Volta region of Ghana. He is the author of the 1995 poetry collection, Ete?, A Woman of Africa and Other Poems. His other collections include: Journey Without End And Other Poems (1997) and Celestial Bride and other poems (2002). Wosornu received his MB,ChB and MD from Glasgow University in 1963 and 1972 respectively. He worked as a Professor and Consultant in Surgery in Saudi Arabia from 1980 to 2007. Wosornu was a fellow at Ghana College of Physicians and Surgeons in 2009 and a fellow at Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2016.

Biography:
Kofi Awoonor was born in 1935 in Wheta, Ghana. A critically acclaimed poet and a stateman, Awoonor is the author of the 1971 poetry collection  titled Night of my Blood. Other collections include: Ride Me, Memory (1973), The House by the Sea (1978), Until the Morning After (1987), The Promise of Hope: New and Selected Poems 1964-2013 (2014), and a novel titled This Earth, My Brother (1971). Awoonor attended the University of Ghana, Legon. He was awarded prizes such as Gurrey prize (1959), Commonwealth poetry award (1989), Ghana Association of Writers distinguished authors award (1991) and ECRAG national award for poetry in 1992 and 1994 respectively. He was killed in 2013 during the attack on West Mall Gate, Kenya.

Biography: Atukwei Okai was born in 1941 in Accra, Ghana. His first collection of poems, Flowerfall, was published in June 1969. His other collections include Oath of the Fontonfrom and Other Poems (1971), Lorgorligi: Logarithms and Other Poems (1974), Freedom Symphony: Selected and New Love Poems (2008) and Mandela the Spear and Other Poems (2013). Okai’s poems have been translated into several languages and anthologized over the years. Rooted in oral tradition, his writings have been recognized as having Pan-Africanist vision. In 1961, on a scholarship from the government of President Kwame Nkrumah, he went to Moscow, where he earned his MA at Maxim Gorky Literature Institute in 1967. He later received his M.Phil from the School of Slavonic and East European Studies in London in 1971. He was Secretary-General of the Pan African Writers' Association in 1989. Okai died in 2018 in Accra.

Biography:
Kojo Laing, born in 1946, was a Ghanian poet and writer known for using Ghanaian Pidgin English alongside standard English in his works. He wrote poetry mostly in the 1970s and was known for his surrealist technique. His novel Search Sweet Country, which was published in 1986, won prizes including the Valco Award and the Ghana Book Award.

Biography: Naana Banyiwa Horne was born 1949 in Kumasi, Ghana. In her work, she explores the themes of womanhood and female subjectivity and critiques traditional subordinate roles expected of women. She is the author of “Sunkwa: clingings onto life” (2000) which examines and celebrates the complex histories and identities of diaspora living. She went to the University of Cape Coast, Ghana, for her bachelors in English and Education. She also received her masters in English from the University of Floride and her PhD in African Languages and Literature from University of Wisconsin-Madison (1993). She joined the faculty of Santa Fe College, Gainesville, in Florida in 2001 where she is currently an Associate Professor of English and African Studies.

Biography: Victoria Bulley was born in 1991in London. She is the author of the chapbook collection, Girl B (Akashic), selected as part of the New-Generation African Poets series and winner of an Eric Gregory Award. Poet, writer, and filmmaker, her work was shortlisted for the African Poetry Prize in 2016. She went to University of Kent for her undergraduate studies in English & Drama (2013). She also received her masters in Postcolonial Studies from SOAS University of London in 2015. Her debut poetry collection, Quiet, is set to be released in 2023. Bulley is a Creative Writing doctoral student at Royal Holloway, University of London.

Biography: Nii Ayikwei Parkes was born 1974 in the United Kingdom and raised in Ghana, where his parents are from. He has written five collections of poetry including eyes of a boy, lips of a man (1999), M is for Madrigal (2004), The Makings of You (2010), Ballast (2009) and his latest work, The Geez (2020), which explores the intersections of self and contemporary culture and was longlisted for the Rathbones Folio Prize and was a Poetry Book Society 2020 Recommendation. Co-founder and Senior Editor at flipped eye publishing, Parkes holds a BSc from Manchester Metropolitan University and an MA in Creative Writing from Birkbeck (University of London). He is the 2007 recipient of Ghana’s national ACRAG award for poetry and literary advocacy and serves on the boards of the Poetry Book Society and the AKO Caine Prize.

Biography: Mukoma Wa Ngugi was born in Evanston, Illinois in 1971, and grew up in Kenya. He holds a BA in English and Political Science from Albright College, an MA in Creative Writing from Boston University, and a PhD in English from University of Wisconsin, Madison. He is the author of the poetry collections, Hurling Words at Consciousness (2006) and Logotherapy (2016), as well as novels and critical books on African literature and politics. A prolific writer and academic, Mukoma Wa Ngugi was shortlisted for the Caine Prize for African Writing in 2009 and the Penguin Prize for African Writing in 2010. He is the co-founder of the Mabati-Cornell Kiswahili Prize for African Literature.

Biography: Koumanthio Zeinab Diallo was born 1956 in Labé, Guinea and grew up in the Fulani culture of ancient Fouta Djallon. Novelist and playwright, she is wellknown for her advocacy for African women, her critiques against forced marriage and use of tales inscribed in oral literature to represent her country’s culture. Her poetry collection, Les rires du silence (The Joys of Silence) received the received a prize from the President of the Republuc of Guinea in 2005. In 1980, she earned an Engineering diploma from the Gamal Abdel Nasser University of Conakry. She set up Guinean branch of the PEN Club International and is a member of the International Committee of Women Writers. She is also the President of the International Commission of African Women Poets and Writers

Biography: Abubakar Othman was born in 1958n in Madagali, Adamawa. He is a critically acclaimed writer whose publications include The Palm of Time (2000, Malthouse), The Passions of Cupid (2013, Kraftbooks), and The Blood Streams in the Desert (2013 Kraftbooks). He holds a PhD in Literary Psychoanalysis and teaches Creative Writing at the University of Maiduguri.

Biography: Mary-Alice Daniel was born 1986 in Maiduguri, Borno State, Nigeria and raised in England and Nashville. Her chapbook, Blood for the Blood God, was published by The New Generation African Poets Series in 2017. Her first book of poetry, Mass for Shut-Ins, is the winner of the 2022 Yale Younger Poets Prize and is forthcoming from Yale University Press in April 2023. She received her BA from Yale University in 2008 and her MFA from University of Michigan in 2013. Also, in 2021, she received her doctorate degree in English Literature from University of Southern California.

Biography: Olu Oguibe was born in Aba, Nigeria, in 1964. An award-winning artist, academic, and writer, he has worked as a professor of art and African American studies and was a fellow at the Vera List Center for Art and Politics in 2000. He was a senior fellow of the Smithsonian Institution in 2006, and a resident scholar at the Rockefeller Study and Conference Center in Bellagio, Italy in 1999. He has published three books of poetry: I Am Bound to this Land by Blood (2013), A Song from Exile (1990), and A Gathering Fear, which won the 1992 Christopher Okigbo All-Africa Prize for Literature.

Biography: Ifi Amadiume was Born in 1947 in Kaduna, Nigeria. A scholar, anthropologist and poet, Amadiume is the author of several collections of poetry including Passion Waves (London: Karnak House, 1985), Ecstasy (Longman Nigeria, 1995), Passion Circles of Love (Africa World Press, 2006) and Voices Draped in Black (Africa World Press 2007).  She is also the author of several books of scholarship including Male Daughters, Female Husbands: Gender and Sex in an African Society (1987) and Reinventing Africa: Matriarchy, Religion and Culture (1997, Zed Books). She studied at the University of London earning her BA in 1978 and her Phd in 1984. She was a professor of religion at Dartmouth College.

Biography: Nduka Otiono was born 1964 in Kano, Nigeria. His poetry collection, Voice in the Rainbow (1997) was a finalist for the ANA/Cadbury Poetry Prize. The writer is known to employ ancestral oral tradition and experimental elements as he writes about the diasporic world. In 2019, he edited the anthology “Camouflage," which featured the best contemporary writing from Nigeria. Teacher and researcher, he obtained his BA and MA degrees from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria. He also received his PhD in English & Film Studies from the University of Alberta in 2011. Before relocating to Canada in 2006, he worked as a journalist in Nigeria and served as General Secretary of the Association of Nigerian Authors (ANA). He is a a two-time recipient of the Carnegie African Diaspora Fellowship (2015 and 2016). Otiono is an Assistant Professor at the Institute of African Studies, Carleton University, Ottawa, Canada.

Biography:
Gabriel Okara was born in 1921 in Nigeria; he was known as as the first Modernist poet of Africa. Okara's poetry often concerns the impact of colonialism and Western influence on African culture and literature. His work incorporates African religion and folklore. He has received several awards for his work, though he is best known for his novel The Voice, published 1964.

Biography: Dan Wylie was born in 1959 in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe. His poetry collection, The Road Out (1996), won the 1998 Ingrid Jonker and Olive Schreiner prizes. His other works include Road Work (2007), Slow Fires (2013), and Raven Games (2017). Poet, novelist and essayist, he concentrates on ecological issues in his writings, with further interests in the history of Shaka Zulu and Zimbabwean literature. In 1995, he earned his Ph.D. on white myths of Shaka from Rhodes University, Makhanda, South Africa, where he remains Professor Emeritus.

Biography: Ngwatilo Mawiyoo was born in 1983 in Nairobi, Kenya. Her chapbook, Dagoretti Corner, was published in 2016 as part of the New Generation African Poets series. She is also the author of poetry collection, Blue mothertongue (2010). Writer, filmmaker and poet, she has been twice shortlisted for Brunel University’s African Poetry Prize, and twice nominated for the Pushcart Prize. In her work, she explores diverse rural Kenyan communities and its geohistories. Ngwatilo has a BA in Music from St. Lawrence University and in 2016, she received her MFA in Creative Writing from the University of British Columbia. She lives in Kenya.

Biography: Ashur Etwebi was born 1952 in Tripoli, Libya. He is the author of six poetry collections including Qsaed Al-Shorfa (Balcony Poems, 1993), Asdiqaoka Maro Min Hu (Your Friends Passed This Way, 2002), and Poems from Above the Hill: Selected Poems of Ashur Etwebi (2011). Poet, novelist and translator, his work reflect the culture, oral tradition and history of Libya and he also combines the traditional Libyan art of poetry with modern elements. After the fall of Muammar Gadafi, he played an important role in establishing cultural and literary festivals Libyan poetry. He received his Bachelor’s degree in medicine from Tripoli University in 1980 and his Doctorate degree from University College Galway, Ireland in 1990. Etwebi was a professor of medicine at the University of Zawia and he now lives in Norway.

Biography: Esther Nirina was born in 1932 on the central highlands of Madagascar. From 1953 to 1983, she lived and worked as a librarian at Orléans, France. She is the author of several poetry collections including Lente spirale (Spiral Lens) (1990), Multiple solitude (1997), Rien que lune : Oeuvres poétiques (Nothing but the Moon: Poetic Works) (1998), among others. Her second volume of poetry, Simple voyelle, was awarded the ADELF Grand Prix Littérature de Madagascar. In her writings, she focuses on themes of unity, creation, and after joining the group, "Les Amis de Rochefort," she learned about surrealism, which influenced her style of writing. She returned from France in 1990 and died in 2004 in Antananarivo, Madagascar.

Biography: Refiloe Mabejane (née Letokoto) was born in South Africa. She went to the University of Johannesburg where she studied psychology. She also received a Master's in International Development at the University of East Anglia in the UK. In addition to her performance poetry, ficition, and creative non-fiction, she works as an professional in international development, specializing in gender issues. She is a trustee and founding member of the non-profit organization ‘Family Art and Literacy Centre.’
year_degree_institution: ["2010 MA, Gender Analysis of International Development: University of East Anglia", "2005 BA, Psychology: University of Johannesburg"]

Biography: Umar Timol was born in 1970 in Mauritius. Poet, fiction writer and visual artist, he is the author of poetry collections La Parole Testament (2003), Sang (2004), and Vagabondages (2008). His other poetry collection, 52 Fragments pour l’aimée (52 Fragments for the Beloved) was the recipient of the 2016 Poetry Prize at the Moldova Poetry Festival. He received his BA in French Language and Literature from the University College London in 1993. Timol is currently at work on a project called ‘Muslim Faces : Breaking the Stereotypes’ where the writer engages in dialogue with Muslims to capture their stories as a way to resist stereotypes perpetuated in the media and create a platform to showcase the real and complex identities of Muslims.

Biography: Ahmed Barakat was born in 1960 in Casablanca, Morocco. He worked as a journalist for the Moroccan newspaper, Bayane Al Yawm, until his death in 1994 at the age of 34. He published two poetry collections including Abadan lan Ussai’da Azzilzal (Never will I sustain the schism). His poems, “Afterwards,” “Black Pain” and “The Torn Flag” were translated by Norddine Zouitni in 2012 and published in Poems for the Millennium, an anthology of traditional and experimental literary texts by North African writers. He was known for championing the prose poem in Morocco and is considered the first writer in the country to write a manifesto defending and celebrating this poetic form. The manifesto, titled “We Are Diggers of Wells, or the Unsigned Manifesto,” was written in 1993 during a poetry festival of Salé and has since been known as the Salé prose poem manifesto. In his poetry, the writer reflected on the urban cosmopolitan experience, work that is often regarded as a tribute to the city of Casablanca.

Biography: Amina Bakouri was born in 1969 in Taza, Morocco. She is most well known for writing contemporary women’s poetry through the lens of the Arab tradition where she challenges patriarchal authority. Her poetry collection, Ra'ian Ya'tika Lmadih, was published in 2002. She received her Ph.D. in Arab literature from the Faculty of letters, Rabat, Morocco. In her work, the poet makes references to the Arabic poetic heritage, and her writing style has been described as embodying a spiritual aura. Like other contemporary Moroccan female writers, Bakouri uses complex interrelationships between different texts as a guide to literary interpretation, an approach that is largely connected to Morocco’s past poetic memory.

Biography: Wafaa Lamrani was born in 1960 in Ksar el-Kebir, Morocco. Her poems “The Wail of Heights” and “I am Consecrated to the Coming One” were featured in The poetry of Arab women: A Contemporary Anthology (2015). She’s also contributed work to Poetic justice: An anthology of contemporary Moroccan poetry (2020). History and politics are strong influences in her work and the writer reflects the hardships and cultural norms of her country in her poems. In 1982, she received her diploma in Arabic Literature from College of Literature and Humanities, Rabat. Lamrani was one of the five women poets featured in La carte poétique du Maroc

Biography: Rethabile Masilo was born in 1961 in Morija, Lesotho. He fled Lesotho to the United States in 1981, and as a student refugee, he received a BSc in Biology from Maryville College in Tennessee in 1986. He relocated and settled in Paris, France in 1987. His poetry draws attention to the grief and trauma associated with Lesotho’s political struggles. He is the author of Waslap (2015), which won the Glenna Luschei Prize for African Poetry. He is also the recipient of the Dalro First Prize in poetry and the Thomas Pringle Award for Poetry. Masilo is the co-editor of literary journal, Canopic Jar.

Biography: Noémia de Sousa was born 1926 in Catembe, near the city of Maputo, Mozambique. Known as the Mother of Mozambican poets, she is the author of Sangue Negro (Black Blood), published in 2001. Regarded as anti-colonial literature, her writings represent cultural nationalism and the resistance of African women under Portuguese colonial domination in the 1940s. Although she was jailed for her political activism, her literary contributions played a crucial role in creating awareness about the Moçambicanidade movement. Poet and newspaper editor, de Sousa edited the women’s pages of the newspaper O Brado Africano from 1949 to 1951. She left Mozambique in 1951 and settled permanently in Portugal, where she died in 2002.

Biography: Inua Ellams was born 1984 in Jos, Nigeria and moved to England with his family when he was 12. Playwright, performer, and poet, he explores themes of identity, displacement, and destiny in his work. He is also known to incorporate hip pop rhymes in his writings and experiment with the blend of traditional and contemporary styles. He is a member of the Royal Society of Literature and has received several awards including the 2020 Hay Medal for Poetry, the 2019 Magma Poetry Prize, and the 2018 Winchester Poetry Prize. He first full-length poetry collection, The Actual (2020), was longlisted for the Derek Walcott Poetry Prize. Ellams studied at Firhouse Community College in Dublin, Ireland from 1999-2002 and in 2006, he attended a Poetry in Education Training programme by Apples and Snakes, UK’s leading spoken word organization. He lives in London.

Biography: Harry Garuba was born 1958 in Akure, Nigeria. At 24, he published his debut collection, Shadow and Dream and Other Poems (1982) which was first runner-up in the inaugural All-Africa Okigbo prize for poetry. In 1988, he received his MA and PhD from University of Ibadan, where he also served as an assistant lecturer in the English department from 1981 to 1997. Garuba was a member of the editorial advisory board of the Heinemann African Writers Series and was well known for his active interest in African and postcolonial literatures. In 1998, he moved to South Africa and joined the faculty at University of Cape Town in 2001. He died Cape Town at the age of 61.

Biography: Pete Kalu was born in 1965 in Manchester, UK. He is the author of the 1996 poetry collection Mongrel Moon. Raised by a Danish mother and Nigerian father, Kalu explores cultural diversity in his work with a research focus on Postcolonial revisions of Imperial history, Black British crime fiction, and YA fiction. He attended Lancaster University for his PhD in Creative Writing and has a first degree in Law from Leeds University. A fiction writer and playwright, he has written several film scripts and radio and theatre plays, including No Trace, winner of the 2002 Kodak/ Liverpool Black Film Festival Award. Kalu was the elected Fellow for the Royal Society for the Arts in 2013 and was recognized among the Top 50 Black British Writers 2019: Speaking Volumes.

Name Built: Lara, Alda 'Alda Ferreira Pires Barreto de Lara Albuquerque'
Biography: Lara Alda was born 1930 in Benguela, in the Portuguese colony of Angola. Poet, essayist and political activist, she writes with a sense of social consciousness on a variety of themes including memories of her own childhood, motherhood, racial identity, and national liberation. She is the author of Poemas (1966), Tempo da Chuva (1973), Poesia (1979), and Poemas (1984) (her collected poems), all of which were published posthumously in Portuguese. She studied in the department of medicine at the University of Lisbon and the University of Coimbra. The Alda Lara Prize (in Portuguese, Prémio Alda Lara) was established in her honour. She died at the age of thirty-two in Cambambe Angola, after her return from Portugal where she lived for 13 years.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Lisbon", " : University of Coimbra"]

Biography: Ana Mafalda Leite was born 1956 in Aveiro, Portugal. She is the author of several poetry collections including Window to the Indian Ocean (2020), Love this form of ignorance (2010) and Roses of China (1999). She went to the Faculty of Arts of the University of Lisbon for her undergraduate studies in Romance Philology. She also received her masters in Brazilian and African Literatures of Portuguese Language and Ph.D. in African Literatures from the same university. Scholar and editor, her areas of research include Mozambican literature, African cultures and literatures in the Portuguese language, oral literature and postcolonial studies. Leite is an Associate Professor of African Literatures at the Faculty of Arts of the University of Lisbon.

Biography: Aracelis Girmay was born 1977 in Santa Ana, CA to an American mother and Ethiopian father. Her first collection Teeth (2007) won the Great Lakes Colleges Association New Writers Award. Her second book, Kingdom Animalia, which examines illness, death, and shame, was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award for Poetry in 2011. She went to Connecticut College for her undergrad in documentary studies and received her MFA from New York University. In 2011, Girmay was awarded a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts, and in 2015 she received a Whiting Award for Poetry. She is currently the Editor-at-Large for BOA Editions' Blessing the Boats Selections, and she also serves on the editorial board of the African Poetry Book Fund. She teaches at Hampshire College and lives in New York City.

Biography: Jaji Tsitsi Ella was born in 1976 in Nyadire Mission, Zimbabwe. A poet and an associate professor of English at Duke University, she is the author of the award-winning academic book, Africa in Stereo: Modernism, Music, and Pan-African Solidarity, and poetry books such as Carnaval and Beating the Graves. She studied Piano and Literature at Oberlin College, and Comparative Literature at Cornell University. She has received fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities/Schomburg Center, Mellon Foundation, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Studies, and National Humanities Center.

Biography: Warsan Shire was born 1988 in Nairobi, Kenya. As a first-generation immigrant raised in London, her chapbooks, Teaching My Mother How To Give Birth (2011) and Her Blue Body (2015) explore the experiences of immigrants, refugees and other marginalized groups. In 2017, her work was featured in the Penguin Modern Poets series, Your Family, Your Body. She is the first ever Young Poetry Laureate of London and in 2014, was chosen as the poet-in-residence for Queensland, Australia. A recipient of the inaugural Brunel International African Poetry Prize in 2013, she has a Bachelor of Arts degree in Creative Writing from London Metropolitan University. Her full-length debut collection, Bless the Daughter Raised by a Voice in Her Head, is forthcoming in March 2022. Residing in Los Angeles now, she works as the poetry editor for SPOOK magazine.

Biography:
Osman Ladan was born in Mogadishu, Somali and raised in Columbus, Ohio. She is the author of Exiles of Eden (2019), a collection of poems that explore displacement and alienation, notably among refugees. Osman wrote The Kitchen-Dweller’s Testimony, poems that examine the limitations of space, imagination, and capacities, and it won the Sillerman First Book Prize for African Poets in 2014. She received her BA from Otterbein College and an MFA from the University of Texas at Austin’s Michener Center for Writers. A Pushcart nominee, she has received fellowships from the Lannan Foundation, Cave Canem, the Michener Center, and the Fine Arts Work Center. She was the recipient of the 2021 Whiting Award.

Biography: Samiya Bashir was born in 1970 in Ypsilanti, Michigan. A professor and lesbian poet, she is the author of poetry chapbooks Wearing Shorts on the First Day of Spring (1999), American Visa (2001) and Teasing Crow (2006). Her full-length collections include Where the Apple Falls (2005), Gospel (2009), a Lambda Literary Award finalist, and Field Theories (2017), which won the Oregon Book Award. As an activist, her work focuses on civil rights struggles and engages multiple landscapes of her own queer identity and politics. Bashir attended the University of California, Berkeley in 1994 where she received her BA in Literature of American Ethnic Cultures and served as Poet Laureate. In 2011, she studied Poetry for the People, an arts/activism program founded by June Jordan, in the University of Michigan. She was the first black woman to be awarded the Rome Prize by the American Academy in Rome in 2019. She joined the Reed College faculty in 2012, where she teaches poetry writing.

Biography:
Born in England in 1932, Sheila Fugard moved to South Africa with her family at age eight. She is a writer of poetry, novels, and plays. Her book The Castaways won the Olive Schreiner Prize.

Biography: Malan Lucas was born in 1946 in Modimolle, South Africa. He has published seven volumes of poetry including ’n Bark vir die ontheemdes (A Barque for the Displaced Ones, 1981), Tydspoor (Time Trail, 1985) and Edenboom (Eden Tree, 1987). He received his BA degree and Higher Education Diploma from the University of Pretoria. He also earned his MA in Afrikaans poetry from the University of the Witwatersrand and his PhD from the University of Pretoria. He continued on to become a lecturer until his retirement in 1997. He died in Cape Town, South Africa in 2010.

Biography: Gail Dendy was born in Durban, South Africa. She is the author of poetry collections The Lady Missionary (2007), Closer Than That (2011), On Days Such as This (2021), among others. Novelist, playwright, and poet, she is the recipient of the 2011 Sol Plaatje/European Union Poetry Award and a finalist for the Herman Charles Bosman Award (Poetry). Her work has been featured in anthologies, including Latest A Field of Large Desires (Manchester: Carcanet, 2010; The Sol Plaatje/European Union Poetry Anthology 2011 (Cape Town: Jacana, 2011), and Africa, My Africa! (African Sun Press, 2012). Dendy received her Bachelors and Masters from the University of South Africa in 1983 and 1985 respectively. She also holds a Higher Diploma in Library Science from Natal University, Pietermaritzburg (now called University of KwaZulul-Natal) (1978). She was Production Editor of the South African Law Journal founded in 1884, and over the years, has worked as a lecturer, copywriter, and Information Specialist.

Biography: Marlene van Niekerk was born in 1954 in Western Cape, South Africa. Her first poetry volume, Sprokkelster (1977), won the Eugène Marais Prize and the Ingrid Jonker Prize. Her other poetry collection, Kaar, won three national prizes: The Herzog prize, the Elisabeth Eybers Prize and the University of Johannesburg prize. Poet, novelist, critic and short story writer, she is known to examine post-apartheid South African society in her work. In 2011, she was awarded South Africa’s high honour, the Order of Ikhamanga, for her “outstanding intellectual contribution to literary arts and culture field through poetry, literature and philosophical works.” She is a Professor of Afrikaans and Dutch literature and Creative Writing at Stellenbosch University in South Africa.

Biography: Dawn Garisch was born 1958 in Zimbabwe, and moved to South Africa when she was nine. She is the author of two poetry collections: Difficult Gifts (2011) and Disturbance (2020). In 2007, her poem ‘Blood Delta’ was awarded the DALRO prize, and in 2011, her poem ‘Miracle’ won the EU Sol Plaatjie Poetry Award. A novelist and poet, her interest is in trans-disciplinary work in science and art. Garisch is the founder of the Life Righting Collective, a writing course and mentorship program aimed to support writers in South Africa and guide them in engaging writing as a recovery process. She a practicing medical doctor and lives in Cape Town, South Africa.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of Cape Town"]

Biography: Shabbir Banoobhai was born to Indian parents in 1949 in Saville Street located in the city of Durban. He has published many poetry collections including echoes of my other self (1980), shadows of a sun-darkened land (1984), lyrics to paradise (2004), and the drums beat all night (2013) in which he explores spirituality and celebrates divinity in humanity. He went to the University of South Africa (Unisa) for his Bachelor of Commerce Degree. Ranked among South Africa’s most acclaimed poets, Banoobhai has successfully established himself as an accountant, a political activist and a spiritual thought leader as he continues to write reflections on love, leadership, and philosophy.

Biography: Nadine Botha was born in 1979 in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa. Poet, journalist and curator, she is the author of two poetry collections: Compared to Not Eating Tuna and Chocolate (2013) and Ants Moving The House Millimetres (2005). She went to Rhode University for her BA in Theory of Art and in 2015, she earned her MA in Design Curating and Writing from Design Academy Eindhoven. As a research designer, Botha’s work explores how political, scientific and cultural systems shape the designs in our in material reality. She lives in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

Biography: Dladla Angifi was born in 1950 in Gauteng, South Africa. He is the author of poetry collections The Girl Who Then Feared To Sleep (2001), We are All Rivers (2010) and an isiZulu collection titled Uhambo (2013). Through his work, Angifi criticized the South African government and reflected on a progressive future where oppressive structures are dismantled, and hope is restored. Creative writing teacher and founder of Femba Writing Project (FWP), the poet and playwright is known to use writing as a political tool to challenge the colonizing practices that shape the teaching and writing of poetry in South Africa. He went to the University of South Africa for his Bachelors and the University of the Witwatersrand for an Honours in publishing in 1997. He died in Katlehong in Gauteng, South Africa in 2020.

Biography: Sarah Johnson was born in 1980, South Africa. She is most well known for her collection Personae which assumes the identities of a variety of figures, exploring the intersection between the devotional and the erotic, among other things. She went to university of Cape Town for her undergraduate in English and Linguistics. She also received her MA in Creative Writing from University of the Cape Town. Personae was published in 2004 and described by accomplished South African poet, Stephen Watson as “one of the best debut volumes in recent years.”

Biography: Haarhoff Dorian was born 1944 in Kimberley, South Africa. He is the author of eight poetry collections, the most recent being ZenPenYen (2022). He edited The Inner Eye (1997), a poetry volume by students of the University of Namibia and the Windhoek College of Education. His writing is influenced by literary tradition, mythology, narrative therapy and ubuntu. He received his BA from Rhodes University (1965) and the University of South Africa (1972). He also holds a Master’s from Rand Afrikaans University (1983) and a D.Phil. from the University of York in England. A former Professor of English Literature at the University of Namibia, he facilitates creative writing workshops and serves as a mentor in writing residencies throughout South Africa.

Biography: Peter Horn was born 1934 in Teplice, Czech. He is most well known for his anti-Apartheid poetry, which caused him to face disciplinary hearings and threats of deportation. His work envisions a multiracial society, advocates for freedom, and captures the experiences of the oppressed. He went to the University of Witwatersrand where he pursued a doctorate in German Studies (1970). In 2000, he was a Finalist for the Caine Prize for African Literature. He was the recipient of the 2011 SALA Literary Lifetime Award for his contribution to literature in South Africa. In 1974, Horn joined the staff at the University of Cape Town (UCT) and was made an Honorary Lifetime Fellow at UCT in 1994. He died in 2019 in Johannesburg.
year_degree_institution: [" : University of the Witwatersrand"]

Biography: Ndaba Sibanda is a Bulawayo-born poet, novelist, and nonfiction writer. A prolific and critically-acclaimed writer, he is the author of The Gushungo Way, Sleeping Rivers, Love O’clock, The Dead Must Be Sobbing, Football of Fools, Cutting-edge Cache, Of the Saliva and the Tongue, When Inspiration Sings In Silence, The Way Forward, Poetry Pharmacy, Sometimes Seasons Come With Unseasonal Harvests, As If They Minded, and The Dangers Of Child Marriages: Billions Of Dollars Lost In Earnings And Human Capital. Ndaba has been nominated for National Arts Merit Awards, The Pushcart Prize and Best of the Net.

Biography: Safia Elhillo was born in 1990 in Rockville, Maryland. A Sudanese by way of Washington DC, Elhillo is an award-winning poet and the author of poetry books such as The Life and Times of Susie Knuckles (2012), ars poetica (2016), a suite for ol' dirty (2016) Asmarani (2016), The January Children (2017), Home Is Not A Country (2021), and Girls That Never Die (2022). Elhillo earned her B.A. at Gallatin School, New York University, and her MFA in Poetry at The New School. She received the Sillerman First Book Prize for African Poets and the Arab American Book Award in 2015 and 2018 respectively.

Biography: Leila Chatti is a Tunisian-American writer and author of Deluge (2020), her debut full-length poetry collection that explores themes of illness, grief, misogyny, and religious beliefs. Her other publications are Tunsiya/Amrikiya (2018) and Ebb (2018), a chapbook part of the anthology of emerging African poets by African Poetry Book Fund. She graduated from Michigan State University in 2011 and in 2015, received her M.F.A. from North Carolina State University, where she was awarded the Academy of American Poets Prize. Her poems, which blend personal narrative with the close examination of the enactment of faith and its complexities, have received numerous prizes including the Pushcart Prize. She lives in Cincinnati, Ohio, where she is pursuing a PhD in creative writing at the University of Cincinnati as a Provost Fellow.

Biography: Tahar Bekri was born in 1951 in Gabès, Tunisia. A poet and literary critic, he has published several poetry collections, including La nostalgie des rosiers sauvages (2014) and Mûrier triste dans le printemps arabe (2016). Important themes in his work include exile, wandering, discovery of new worlds, and the reinvention of cultures. In 1970, he obtained his BA in Modern Literature from the University of Tunis. Considered one of the leading voices of contemporary North African literature, Bekri’s work has been the subject of academic research and translated into several languages (Russian, English, Italian, Spanish, Turkish, etc). In 1993, he was awarded the Order of Cultural Merit by the Tunisian Republic and in 2018, became the laureate of the Benjamin Fondane International Prize for Francophone Literature.

Biography: Melissa Kiguwa was born 1990 in London, UK to a Haitian father and a Ugandan mother. She is the author of the 2014 poetry collection Reveries of Longing that covers themes of migration, imperialism, sexuality, and spirituality. The collection was selected as one of This is Africa’s 100 Best Books in fiction, poetry, memoir, and nonfiction. In 2011, Kiguwa graduated from the University of Arizona with a BS in Political Science and received her MSc. in Media, Communication, Development in 2015 from the London School of Economics. She is a 2020 PEN America Emerging Voices Fellow and host of Grit and Grace podcast, in collaboration with the London School of Economics Accelerator for Women Founders.

Biography: Nick Makoha was born in 1974 in Busia, Uganda. He is the author of Resurrection Man, winner of the 2016 Toi Derricotte + Cornelius Eady Chapbook Prize. Novelist and poet, he explores a range of subjects in his work including exile, displacement, civil war, and the impact of imperialism and neo-colonialism. He went to Queen Mary University of London for his BSc in Biochemistry (1996). He also earned his MA in Creative Writing from Goldsmith, University of London and his PhD in Creative Writing in King’s College, London. He is a Cave Canem Graduate Fellow and co-winner of the 2015 Brunel International African Poetry prize. Makoha is the founder of The Obsidian Foundation and a member of Malika’s Poetry Kitchen collective.

Biography: Hope Wabuke was born 1981 in Minnesota. She has published three chapbooks: her (2019), The Leaving (2016), and Movement No.1 (2015). She went to Northwestern University in 2002 for her undergrad in Film and Media Studies and Creative Writing. Wabuke also received her MFA in Creative Writing from New York University in 2007. An Assistant Professor of English and Creative Writing, her research interests include African and African Diasporic Literature, Literary & Cultural Criticism and Women's and Gender Studies. A finalist for the 2015 Brunel University African Poetry Prize, she has received fellowships and awards from the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Book Critics Circle, Cave Canem, among others. She is the Poetry Editor for Ruminate Magazine and teaches at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

Biography:
Born 1959, Ben Okri is a Nigerian poet and writer, writing primarily in the postcolonial and postmodern tradition. Okri's success as a writer began when he published his first novel Flowers and Shadows in 1980. He served West Africa magazine as poetry editor from 1983 to 1986, and was a regular contributor to the BBC World Service between 1983 and 1985.

Biography: Tanure Ojaide was born in Nigeria in 1948. He has a B.A. in English from University of Ibadan, Nigeria, and an M.A. (Creative Writing) and Ph.D. (English) from Syracuse University. An accomplished poet and academic, Ojaide is the author of many collections of poetry including Narrow Escape: A Poetic Diary of the Coronavirus Pandemic (2021), The Questioner (2018), Love Gifts (2013), The Beauty I Have Seen (2010), and Songs of Myself: A Quartet (2015), which won the 2018 Wole Soyinka Prize for Literature in Africa. He has won other awards for poetry including the Commonwealth Poetry Prize for the Africa Region (1987), the All-Africa Okigbo Prize for Poetry (1988, 1997), the BBC Arts and Africa Poetry Award (1988), and the Association of Nigerian Authors Poetry Award (1988, 1994, 2003, and 2011). He is currently the Frank Porter Graham Professor of Africana Studies at The University of North Carolina at Charlotte.

Biography: Finuala Dowling was born 1962 in Cape Town, South Africa. Her first poetry collection, I Flying (2002), was the recipient of the Ingrid Jonker Prize. Her other collections include winner of the Sanlam Award for Poetry, Doo-Wop Girls of the Universe, Penguin (2006), Notes from the Dementia Ward (2008) which won the Olive Schreiner Prize and Pretend You Don't Know Me (2008). She received an MA in English from the University of Cape Town (UCT) in 1986 and a D.Litt. from the University of South Africa (UNISA) in 1995. She was a Senior Lecturer at the Centre for Extra-Mural Studies, University of Cape Town from 2014-2021. Dowling is now a Freelance creative writing lecturer, and she also develops literary scripts which have been performed by John Maytham at a variety of venues in Western Cape.

Biography:
Soyinka took an active role in Nigeria's political history and its struggle for independence from Great Britain. In 1965, he seized the Western Nigeria Broadcasting Service studio and broadcast a demand for the cancellation of the Western Nigeria Regional Elections. In 1967, during the Nigerian Civil War, he was arrested by the federal government of General Yakubu Gowon and put in solitary confinement for two years. In 1986 he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

Biography: Tolu Ogunlesi was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1982, and grew up in Nigeria. He attended University of Ibadan, where he received a Bachelor of Pharmacy in 2004. He also has an MA in Creative Writing from University of East Anglia. A writer and award-winning journalist, Ogunlesi is the author of the poetry collection, Listen to the Geckos Singing from a Balcony (2004). He was awarded the Dorothy Sargent Rosenberg poetry prize in 2006, and the Nordic Africa Institute Guest Writer Fellowship in 2008. In 2016, he was appointed Special Assistant on Digital/New Media to Nigerian president, Muhammadu Buhari.

Biography: Niran Okewole was born in 1977. He is a psychiatrist, playwright, essayist, and poet. He won the MUSON Festival Poetry Prize in 2002 and 2003 and was a recipient of the Sawubona Music Jam/Berlin International Poetry Festival Prize in 2008. Okewole’s poems have appeared in ANA Review, Mindfire Review, Farafina Magazine, African Writing, Saraba, and Maple Tree Literary Supplement. He has published two poetry collections: Logarhythms (2005) and The Hate Artist (2015).

Biography: Ipadeola Tade was born in 1970 in Fiditi, Oyo State. A lawyer and a poet, he was awarded the 2013 NLNG Prize for his poetry collection titled The Sahara Testaments. Ipadeola has authored other poetry books, which include Voices: Interiors and Exteriors (1996), A Time of Signs (2000), and The Rain Fardel (2005). He attended Obafemi Awolowo University, where he graduated with a Law degree in 1991. Ipadeola writes in English and Yoruba, and he has translated two classical Yoruba novels by D.O. Fagunwa into English: The Divine Cryptograph (Aditu); and The Pleasant Potentate of Ibudo (Ireke Onibudo). He was selected for the Iowa Writing Fellowship in 2019.

Biography: Habeebatu X was born in 1997 in Ilorin, Nigeria. She studied Medicine at the Bayero University Kano and has an MBBS degree. She is currently a House Officer in the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital, Kwara State of Nigeria.
year_degree_institution: [" : Bayero University, Kano"]

Biography: Muzanenhamo Togara was born in 1975 in Lusaka, Zambia and spent his childhood in Zimbabwe. Poet and journalist, his first collection, Spirit Brides (2006) was shortlisted for the Jerwood Anderson First Collection Prize. His other poetry collections are Gumiguru (2014), which was also shortlisted for the Glenna Luschei Prize for African Poetry, Textures, winner of the National Arts and Merit Award for Literature, and Virga (2021). In 2001, he received his MA in Creative Writing from Manchester Metropolitan University. He also studied Business Administration in the Netherlands and in France.
